entering upon a thing, beginning, καινὰς ἐσβολὰς ὁρῶ λόγων E. Supp. 92; ἐ. στεναγμάτων Id. Ion 677 (lyr.); σοφισμάτων Ar. Ra. 1104; κανόνων ib. 956; proem, preface, of a play, Antiph. 191.20, cf. D.H. Lys. 17 (pl.), Longin. 38.2.
produce of live-stock, PStrassb. 24.43.
arrive, PGiss. 69.17; dub. in Aeschin. Ep. 11.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὰ εἰσγενόμενα incomings, revenue, PBaden 47 (ii B.C.).
enrolment, εἰς τοὺς ἐφήβους D.C. 59.2.

inscribe, στηλῶν ἐς ἃς οἱ νόμοι ἐσεγράφοντο D.C. 37.9; enrol, τινὰ εἰς τοὺς φίλους Id. 36.53; τινὰς ἐς τὸν κατάλογον Id. Fr. 109.5 ; also of painting, πορφυραῖ σκιαὶ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς εἰς κάλλος -ουσιν Ael. NA 12.25 :— Med., ἐς τὰς σπονδὰς ἐσγράψασθαι ἑαυτούς to have themselves enrolled in the league, Th. 1.31:— Pass., D.C. 61.21.

data.quote: πορφυραῖ σκιαὶ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς εἰς κάλλος -ουσιν

children.definition: write down, μαντεῖα S. Tr. 1167; send in a report, BCH 46.400 ( Mylasa).
lend at interest as well, Pl. R. 555c.
acceptable, LXX Le. 22.29 (s.v.l.).

definition: εἰσδέρκομαι, with aor. Act. εἰσέδρᾰκον: pf. εἰσδέδορκα:—

children.definition: look at or upon, νῆσον ἐσέδρακον ὀφθαλμοῖσιν Od. 9.146; ἐσέδρακον ἄντην Il. 24.223; τί μʼ εἰσδέδορκεν; E. El. 558, cf. Andr. 615.

take into, admit, ἐς τὸ ἱρόν Hdt. 1.144, cf. 206 : c. acc. pers., S. OT 238; εἰ. φρουράν IG 2(2).43.22 : c. acc. loc., οὐκ εἰσεδέξατʼ οἶκον E. Supp. 876: c. dat., ἄντροις εἰ. τινά receive him in the cave, Id. Cyc. 35 : rarely c. gen., τόνδʼ εἰσεδέξω τειχέων, = τειχέων εἴσω ἐδέξω (cf. Sch. ad loc.), E. Ph. 451: c. acc. dupl., ἐσδέξασθαί τινα συνοικιστῆρα admit him as a fellow-colonist, Pi. Fr. 186; εἰ. τινά ὑπόστεγον S. Tr. 376: aor. 1 εἰσδεχθῆναι in pass. sense, Luc. Tox. 30, Merc.Cond. 10.
σκῆψιν ἁγὼν οὗτος οὐκ ἐσδέξεται Ar. Ach. 392; εἰ. εὐνομίαν διὰ τῆς μουσικῆς Pl. R. 425a.
take in their young after birth, Arist. HA 566b17, GA 754a29.
flow into, ἐσ.. dub. l. in Hdt. 4.49, 50.

children.label: II
children.definition: hand in a report or memorandum, εἰ. περί τινος Aristeas 28, prob. in J. AJ 12.2.3:— Pass., τὸ εἰσδοθέν PTeb. 72.462 (ii B.C.); also of a question, to be brought up for discussion, ἐν ἀγάρρει IG 14.759.12.
send in the name of a person liable to service or taxation, BGU 619.8 (ii A.D.), 1198.16 (i A.D.), etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: lay information against, τινά PSI 4.417 (ii B.C.), etc.
pay in, PPetr. 2p.31 (iii B.C.).
report, memorandum, Aristeas 28, 33, PLond. 1.23 iv I (ii B.C.), prob. in J. AJ 12.2.3.
reception, Olymp. in Mete. 5.6; τοῦ σπέρματος Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.64; εἰσδοχαὶ δόμων a hospitable house, E. El. 396.
receipt of corn, etc., PTeb. 123.4 (i B.C.).
inroad, onslaught, E. Rh. 604; of one who throws himself into a besieged place, Th. 2.25; into a house, J. BJ 5.10.3.

definition: εἰσδύω, εἰσδύνω and Med. εἰσδύομαι (v. δύω): fut. - δύσομαι, with aor. 2 - έδῡν: pf. - δέδῡκα:—

children.definition: get or crawl into, ἐς τὸν θησαυρόν Hdt. 2.121.βʹ; ψυχὴ ἐς ἄλλο ζῷον ἐσδύεται ib. 123; εἰσεδύοντο εἰς τοὺς πόδας οἱ ἱμάντες the thongs entered into their feet, X. An. 4.5.14; εἰς τὴν Ἀμφικτυονίαν εἰσδεδυκώς having wormed his way into the League, D. 11.4.
go into, enter, ἀκοντιστὺν ἐσδύσεαι Il. 23.622; ὁ ψὴν τὴν βάλανον ἐσδύνων Hdt. 1.193; ἄκακον..τρόπον εἰσδύς having put on.., Anaxil. 33.3.
οὐκ εἶδεν οὗ γῆς εἰσέδυ saw not into what part of the earth she entered, E. IA 1583.

children.label: II
children.definition: δεινόν τι ἐσέδυνέ σφι great fear came upon them, Hdt. 6.138; εἰσέδυ με..οἴστρημα καὶ μνήμη κακῶν S. OT 1317; [ ἡ ἀλήθεια] εἰς τὰς ψυχὰς εἰσδύεται Plb. 13.5.5; λύπη εἰσδύνουσα Andronic. Rhod. P. 571M.
entrance, Arist. HA 616a28, Agath. 2.5; room for or means of entrance, εἴ. οὐδʼ ἀθέρι prob. in Lyr.Adesp. 2B, cf. Gp. 15.2.26.
approach, dub. l. in Plb. 12.19.6 (prob. ἐγγίζοντα).

definition: εἰσεῖδον, Ep. εἴσῐδον and in Med. form εἰσῐδόμην, v. εἰσοράω.
εἴσειμι, inf. - ιέναι, serving as fut. to εἰσέρχομαι: impf. εἰσῄειν:—

children.definition: enter, go into, οὐδʼ Ἀχιλῆος ὀφθαλμοὺς εἴσειμι I will not come before Achilles’ eyes, Il. 24.463: more freq. with Preps., οὐκ εἴσειμι μετʼ ἀνέρας Od. 18.184; παρὰ βασιλέα Hdt. 1.99; mostly with εἰς, ἐς τὸ μέγαρον ib. 65, etc.; πρός τινα S. Ph. 953, X. Cyr. 2.4.5; ἐσιέναι ἐς σπονδάς enter into a treaty, Th. 5.30 : abs., τὸν εἰσιόντα μῆνα the ensuing month, And. 1.42; τὸν εἰσιόντα ἐνιαυτόν Arist. Ath. 31.2, cf. POxy. 1278.17 (iii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: come upon the stage, enter, Pl. Lg. 664c; τὸ τοὺς τυράννους..εἰσιέναι take the part of king, D. 19.247, cf. Lib. Or. 30.28.

children.label: III
children.definition: come into the assembly, εἰς ἀγοράν D. 24.60; καθʼ ὅτι ἂν ἐσίῃ ἡ πρεσβεία Th. 4.118; of judges, come into court, εἰ. κρινοῦντες D. 18.210.

data.quote: καθʼ ὅτι ἂν ἐσίῃ ἡ πρεσβεία

children.definition: come before the court, εἰς ὑμᾶς Antipho 5.80, etc.; εἰ. περί τινος D. 19.211; πρός τινα Id. 54.32.
ἡ δίκη εἰσῄει Is. 5.17; δίκας εἰσιέναι κατά τινος enter upon actions, D. 28.17, cf. Is. 8.44.
enter on an office, εἰς ἀρχήν D. 59.72 ; ὁ ἐσιών the new king, Hdt. 6.59.

children.label: IV
children.definition: come into oneʼs mind, Ἀστυάγεα ἀνάγνωσις ἐσήιε Id. 1.116; καίτοι μʼ ἐσῄει δεῖμα E. Or. 1668; ἔιεος εἰσῄει με Pl. Phd. 58e : c. dat., ἄιγος εἰσῄει φρενί E. IA 1580, cf. Pl. Phd. 59a ; δέος τινὶ εἰσῄει περί τινος Id. R. 330d.
εἰσῄει αὐτοὺς ὅπως ἂν.. they began to think how they might.., X. An. 5.9.17 : c. inf., οὐδενὸς εἰσῄει μοι φθονεῖν D. 23.188.

children.label: V
children.definition: τὰ εἰσιόντα what enters into one, food, X. Cyr. 1.6.17.
charge, of scythe-chariots, Plu. Art. 7.
celebrated by a triumphal entry, ἀγῶνες εἰ. CIG 2932 ( Tralles), 3426 ( Philadelphia), IGRom. 3.370 ( Adada), cf. Plin. Ep. 10.118; ἱεροὶ εἰ. [ἀγῶνες] Ath.Mitt. 26.239 ( Tralles).

definition: εἰσελαύνω, Ep. εἰσ-ελάω: fut. - ελάσω [ᾰ], Att. - ελῶ:—

children.definition: drive in, ποιμὴν εἰσελάων [τὴν ποίμνην] Od. 10.83; ἵππους δʼ εἰσελάσαντες Il. 15.385; τὴν θήλειαν ὁ ἄρρην εἰ. πρὸς τὰ ᾠά Plu. Sollert. 2.962f ; εἰσελαύνειν τινὰ εἰς τὸν τοῦ πράγματος δρόμον to keep him to the point, Aeschin. 1.176, cf. 3.206.

data.quote: τὴν θήλειαν ὁ ἄρρην εἰ. πρὸς τὰ ᾠά

children.label: II
children.definition: ἔνθʼ οἵ γʼ εἰσέλασαν [τὴν νῆα] that way they rowed in, Od. 13.113; ἐπεὶ εἰσήλασεν εἰς τὴν πόλιν [τὸν ἵππον] when he marched into.., X. An. 1.2.26, etc.: c. acc. loci, εἰ. λιμένα A.R. 2.672, cf. 1265 ; enter in triumphal procession, Plu. Marc. 8; τεθρίππῳ Id. Publ. 9; εἰς τὰς Ἀθήνας Ael. VH 12.58: c. acc. cogn., εἰσελαύνειν θρίαμβον Plu. Mar. 12, Cat.Mi. 31.

definition: εἰσελεύσιον, τό, worse form for εἰσηλύσιον, Gloss.

children.definition: entrance, arrival, Vett.Val. 226.22, Hsch. s.v. ἧξις (prob.l.), Thom.Mag. p.302 R.
draw, haul, in or into, Xenarch. 4.13 : aor. - είλκῠσα Hdt. 2.175, Ar. Ach. 379.
go on board, AP 7.374 ( Marc. Arg., nisi leg. εἰσανέβην).
Hsch.
enter a country as a trader, εἰς τὴν χώραν IG 1(2).57.20: expld. by τὸ εἰς πολεμίους ἐμπορίας χάριν ἀπιέναι, Hsch.
place in, εἰσενέθηκε Epigr.Gr. 517.8 ( Edessa).
for hereafter, τὰ..πάρος τά τʼ εἰ. S. Aj. 35, etc.
visit a foreign state, Pl. Lg. 952d.
shut up in (a mummy-case), τὸν νεκρόν Hdt. 2.86.

to go into, ἐσέρπει ἐς ἄνθρωπον ψυχή Hp. Vict. 1.7, cf. Plu. Cleom. 8; ἐς τὸ ἱερὸν μὴ ἐσέρπεν ( Dor. inf.) IG 12(3).183 ( Astypalaea, iv/iii B.C.); διὰ τοῦ στομίου Luc. DMort. 10[3].2: c. dat., φθόνος βραχέσιν εἰσερπύσας χωρίοις Ph. 2.553.
go into, get in: pf. εἰσήρρηκα Ar. Th. 1075: aor. εἰσήρρησεν Id. Eq. 4, Agath. Praef. p.139D.
binding in or to, Sch. Th. 1.6.
draw into, [νῆα] κοῖλον σπέος εἰσερύσαντες Od. 12.317.

definition: εἰσέρχομαι, fut. - ελεύσομαι: aor. - ήλῠθον, -ῆλθον: in Att., fut. is supplied by εἴσειμι, and impf. by εἰσῄειν:—

children.definition: go in or into, enter, in Hom. and Poets mostly c. acc., Φρυγίην εἰσήλυθον Il. 3.184; ἀλλʼ εἰσέρχεο τεῖχος 22.56; αὐιάν Pi. N. 10.16; ἄλσος, δόμους, S. Tr. 1167, E. Alc. 563; οἴκαδε X. HG 5.4.28; οἴκαδε εἰς ἐμαυτοῦ Pl. Hp.Ma. 304d; εἰσῆλθʼ ἑκατόμβας invaded the hecatombs, Il. 2.321 : but in Prose mostly with Preps., ἐς οἴκημα Th. 1.134, etc.; ἐσ. ἐς τὰς σπονδάς come into the treaty, Id. 5.36; εἰς τὸν πόλεμον v.l. in X. An. 7.1.27; εἰ. εἰς τοὺς ἐφήβους enter the ranks of the Ephebi, Id. Cyr. 1.5.1; also εἰ. πρός τινα enter his house, visit him, ib. 3.3.13; of a doctor, pay a visit, Gal. 18(2).36 ; εἰ. ἐπὶ τὸ δεῖπνον X. An. 7.3.21 : abs., of money, etc., come in, προσόδους εἰσελθούσας Id. Vect. 5.12.

children.label: II
children.definition: come upon the stage, enter, Pl. R. 580b, X. An. 6.1.9, etc.; enter the lists, in a contest, S. El. 700; πρός τινα in competition with.., D. 18.319.

children.label: III
children.definition: come into court, εἰς ὑμᾶς (sc. τοὺς δικαστάς) D. 59.1; but also τοὺς ὑπὲρ τῶν κοινῶν -εληλυθότας δικαστάς Id. 18.278.
εἰ. τὴν γραφήν enter the charge, Id. 18.105; εἰ. δίκας Id. 28.17 (so also εἰ. [τὴν καταχειροτονίαν] Id. 21.6; εἰ. λόγον κατά τινος Arg. Isoc.II).
come before the court, δεῦρο Pl. Ap. 29c; εἰς δικαστήριον Id. Grg. 522b; εἰς ὑμᾶς D. 18.103, cf. 21.176; εἰσελθόντες δʼ ὡς ὑμᾶς is prob. in Arist. Rh. 1410a18.
to be brought in, ποῖ οὖν δεῖ ταύτην εἰσελθεῖν τὴν δίκην; D. 35.49.

children.label: IV
children.definition: enter on an office, Antipho 6.44 ; ἐσ. ἐς τὴν ὑπατείαν D.C. 41.39 ; ἐπὶ τὴν ἀρχήν Id. 64.7.

children.label: V
children.definition: consult a table, εἰ. εἰς ὄργανον Vett.Val. 20.12.

children.label: VI
children.definition: [μένος] ἄνδρας ἐσέρχεται courage enters into the men, Il. 17.157 ; πείνη δʼ οὔ ποτε δῆμον ἐσέρχεται famine never enters the land, Od. 15.407 ; Κροῖσον γέλως ἐσῆλθε Hdt. 6.125 ; ὥς με πόλλʼ εἰσέρχεται.. ἄλγη A. Pers. 845; πόθος μʼ εἰσέρχεται E. IA 1410 ; νιν εἰσῆλθεν τάδε ib. 57 : c. dat., εἰσῆλθε τοῖν τρὶς ἀθλίοιν ἔρις S. OC 372 ; [Κύπρις] εἰσέρχεται μὲν ἰχθύων.. γένει Id. Fr. 941.9 ; δέος εἰ. τινὶ περί τινος Pl. R. 330d ; ὑποψία εἰ. μοι Id. Ly. 218c.
come into oneʼs mind, Κροίσῳ ἐσελθεῖν τὸ τοῦ Σόλωνος Hdt. 1.86, cf. Pl. Tht. 147c ; ἐσελθεῖν τισὶ ἡδονήν, οἶκτον, Hdt. 1.24, 3.14.

children.label: b
children.definition: inf., τὸν δὲ ἐσῆλθε θεῖον εἶναι τὸ πρῆγμα it came into his head that.., Id. 3.42 ; ἐσῆλθέ με κατοικτῖραι Id. 7.46; εἰσῆλθε δή με..φοβηθῆναι Pl. Lg. 835d; τὸν δὲ ἐσῆλθε ὡς εἴη τέρας Hdt. 8.137; εἰσελθέτω σε μήποθʼ ὡς.. A. Pr. 1002.

data.quote: τὸν δὲ ἐσῆλθε ὡς εἴη τέρας

children.definition: still, yet, Theoc. 27.19, etc.
procure in plenty, τὸ πλεῖστον Supp.Epigr. 1.366.40 ( Samos, iii B.C.); χρήματα τῇ πόλει D.S. 16.40 ; ποθόδους τοῖς ἐγχωρίοις GDI 3069 ( Selymbria) : abs., SIG 364.74 ( Ephesus).

stretch into, κόλπος ἐκ τῆς βορηΐης θαλάσσης ἐσέχων ἐπὶ Αἰθιοπίης a bay running in from the north sea towards Ethiopia, Hdt. 2.11 ; ἡ μεγίστη τῶν διωρύχων ἐσέχει ἐς ποταμόν Id. 1.193 ; ἦν θάλαμος ἐσέχων ἐς τὸν ἀνδρεῶνα the chamber opened into the menʼs apartment, Id. 3.78 ; ἐς τὸν οἶκον ἐσέχων ὁ ἥλιος the sun shining into the house, Id. 8.137 : abs., ἐκ τοῦ Νείλου διώρυχες ἐσέχουσι (sc. ἐς τὴν γῆν) Id. 2.138.

data.quote: ἡ μεγίστη τῶν διωρύχων ἐσέχει ἐς ποταμόν

children.label: II
children.definition: τὸ ἐσέχον is the retiring part, the shade, opp. ἐξέχον (the high lights), Philostr. VA 2.20.

children.label: b
children.definition: στέρνα ἐσέχοντα hollow chests, Id. Gym. 35.
lead in, εἰσηγοῦ σὺ λαβὼν ἡμᾶς Ar. Av. 647 ; bring in, introduce, ἀοιδάς Simon. 174 (dub.); of religious rites, Hdt. 2.49; δημαγωγίαν Plb. 2.21.8; ἔθος D.H. 11.50.

introduce, propose, τὴν πεῖραν Th. 3.20; γῆς ἀναδασμούς Pl. Lg. 684e ; νόμον Diph. 38, cf. D. 18.148, etc. ; δόγμα Ph. 1.140, al.; εἰ. περί τινος make a proposal on a subject, Isoc. 4.170 : c. inf., propose, εἰ. τὴν αὐλητρίδα χαίρειν ἐᾶν to let her go, Pl. Smp. 176e, cf. Cri. 48a, cf. D.H. 6.51, Plu. Publ. 16; τοῦτο τὸ μάθημα, ὅτι καλὸν εἴη Pl. La. 179e ; εἰ. ὅπως.. Plu. Them. 20; εἰσηγουμένου τινός at his proposal, on his motion, Th. 4.76, cf. IG 5(1).1451.6 ( Messene, ii A.D.), etc.

data.quote: τοῦτο τὸ μάθημα, ὅτι καλὸν εἴη

children.definition: εἰσηγεῖσθαί τινι represent to a person, ἐσηγεῖται.. τοῖς ἐν τέλει οὖσιν ὡς οὐ χρεών.. Th. 7.73: hence, advise, instruct, τοιαῦτα μέντοὐγὼ φρονεῖν τούτοισιν εἰσηγησάμην Ar. Ra. 972 ; τοῖς νεωτέροις Isoc. 1.4 ; εἰ. τοῖς πολεμίοις ἃ χρὴ καταλαβεῖν τῶν χωρίων Lys. 14.35.

data.quote: ἐσηγεῖται.. τοῖς ἐν τέλει οὖσιν ὡς οὐ χρεών..
εἰ. τοῖς πολεμίοις ἃ χρὴ καταλαβεῖν τῶν χωρίων

children.definition: relate, narrate, explain, τινί τι Pl. Smp. 189d; λόγον τινί Id. Ti. 20d.
motion, proposal, Aeschin. 1.82 : pl., Isoc. Ep. 1.2.
precept, Nic.Dam.p.26D.
proposing, advising, Th. 5.30, Ph. 2.211, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.11d; introduction, ἐθῶν καὶ νομίμων Ph. 1.166 (pl.); δογμάτων ib. 410.

children.label: II
children.definition: a motion, D.C. 36.38.
one must move, Th. 6.90.
Hsch.
one who brings in, author, τῶν κακῶν τῷ δήμῳ Th. 8.48, cf. Hyp. Epit. 3, Arist. Ath. 27.4, Aeschin. 1.172, Ph. 1.103, al., Luc. Anach. 14, etc.
she that introduces, καινοῦ θεοῦ Corn. Rh. p.390H.
reproach, Suid., Zonar.
inject by a syringe, Hdt. 2.87.

to have come in, v.l. in Ar. V. 606; of revenues, BCH 6.18 ( Delos, ii B.C.) : fut., to be about to come in, ἔοικεν.. ἐσήξειν (nisi leg. ἐσᾴξειν) A. Ag. 1181; εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν ἐσήξειν (nisi leg. -ᾴξειν) D.C. 37.32.
coming in, entrance, AP 9.625 ( Maced.).
entrance-fee, IG 2(2).1368.37, Ath.Mitt. 32.294 ( Pergam., ii A.D.).
entrance, right of entrance, CIG 3278 ( Smyrna).

definition: εἶσθα, Ep. 2 sg. of εἶμι ( ibo), Il. 10.450, Od. 19.69.
εἷσθαι, pf. inf. Pass. of ἵημι (v. ἀφίημι).

children.definition: putting in, Ph. 1.278; opp. ἀφαίρεσις, Dam. Pr. 102.

children.label: II
children.definition: insetting of short lines in lyric strophes, Sch. Ar. Pl. 253, Ach. 565.
run into or in, J. BJ 6.4.6, Philostr. VA 1.28, D.C. 62.16, etc.; ἐσθεῖ πρὸς ἡμᾶς runs up to us, Ar. Av. 1169.
investigate, Heph.Astr. 3.37.

definition: εἰσθλίβω [ῑ], prob. f.l. for ἐκθλίβω in Plu. QConv. 2.688b, Them. Or. 14.197a.
εἴσθλιψις, prob. f.l. for ἔκθλ. in Philagr. ap. Orib. 5.17.10.

children.definition: leap into or in, ὁ δʼ ἄρʼ ἔσθορε φαίδιμος Ἕκτωρ Il. 12.462, cf. 21.18 ; διά τινος Ael. NA 14.24: c. acc., πρὶν ἐμὸν ἐσθορεῖν δόμον A. Th. 454 (lyr.).

data.quote: ὁ δʼ ἄρʼ ἔσθορε φαίδιμος Ἕκτωρ

definition: εἰσί, 3 pl. of εἰμί ( sum). εἶσι, 3 sg. of εἶμι ( ibo). εἰσῐδεῖν, Ep. εἰσιδέειν, aor. inf. of εἰσεῖδον; v. εἰσοράω.

children.definition: build in, ἐσίδρυταί σφι Ἄρηος ἱρόν v.l. in Hdt. 4.62.
take oneʼs station in, ἐσίζεσθαι λόχον ἀνδρῶν Il. 13.285.

send into, ἐς τὴν [λίμνην] εἰ. τὸ ὕδωρ, of rivers, Hdt. 7.109; εἰ. τοὺς Πέρσας ἐς τὸ τεῖχος let them in, Id. 3.158; τὴν [κεδρίην] (sc. ἐς τὴν κοιλίην) Id. 2.87:— Med., τοὺς πολεμίους ἔφη εἰσέσθαι said he had let them in, X. HG 1.3.19; χάριτας Sammelb. 4324.8:— Pass., IG 1(2).115.18 (Lex Dracontis).

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., αὖλιν ἐσιέμεναι betaking themselves into their own roost, Od. 22.470.
entrance, Od. 6.264, Opp. H. 1.738.
go into, c. acc. loci, Hermesian. 7.23.

children.label: II
children.definition: penetrate, Hdt. 3.108; εἰσικνουμένου βέλει piercing her with a shaft, A. Supp. 556 (lyr., s. v.l.).
ride into or in, εἰς τὴν πόλιν D.S. 17.12: abs., D.C. 44.10.
one must go in, Iamb. VP 23.105, al.
revenue, BCH 6.26 ( Delos, ii B.C.): pl., Dor. -άματα SIG 244 A 20 (Delph.).

belonging to entrance: εἰσιτήρια (sc. ἱερά), τά, a sacrifice at the beginning of a year or entrance on an office, D. 19.190; εἰ. ὑπὲρ τῆς βουλῆς ἱεροποιῆσαι Id. 21.114, cf. SIG 695.25 ( Magn. Mae., ii B.C.), D.C. 45.17; εἰσιτήριοι θυσίαι Hld. 7.2 : sg., εἰσιτήριον, τό, entrance-deposit, PRyl. 77.37 ( ii A.D., ἰσητ-Pap.):— Att. Inscrr. have εἰσιτητήρια, IG 2(2).17, al.
one must go in, Luc. Herm. 73.
accessible, Alciphr. 1.23; εἰσιτητὰ τῷ στόλῳ ποιεῖν Procop. Vand. 1.20: also εἰσιτός J. BJ 6.4.5, Zonar.
Isis-Fortuna, CIL 4.4138, 14.2867.
dispatch to a place, ἀργύριον εἰσκατιέναι (sic) Ἀθήναζε IG 1(2).6.116.
look down upon, πόλιν ἐσκατορᾷς ( Ion. form), Bgk. for ἐγκ-, Anacr. 1.6.
twenty-first, IG 11(2).164 A 45 ( Delos, iii B.C.).
haul in, as an angler the fish which he has hooked, Ar. V. 381.

call in, μάρτυρας Ar. V. 936, D. 28.5; τινὰ πρὸς αὑτόν X. Cyr. 8.3.1, cf. Theoc. 2.132, PPetr. 2p.31 (iii B.C.), etc.:— Med., invite to oneʼs house, Act. Ap. 10.23; also, call or have called in, Plb. 21.22.2; [ ἰητρόν] Hp. Prog. 1; summon, PPetr. 3p.62 (iii A. D.).
go down into, c. acc., ὄρχατον Od. 24.222; δόμον Orac. ap. Hdt. 5.92.εʹ.
break inwards:— Pass., ἐσκαταρραγῆναι ῥωγμῇσι Hp. VC 17.
put down into:— Med., ἑὴν ἐσκάτθετο νηδύν Hes. Th. 487, 890 (v.l. ἐγκάτθετο).

definition: εἴσκειμαι, used as Pass. of εἰστίθημι,

children.definition: to be put on board ship, Th. 6.32.
put to land, ποίαν δὲ χώραν εἰσεκέλσαμεν σκάφει; Ar. Th. 877.
proclaim by herald, Ar. Ach. 135 ( Pass.), Inscr.Prien. 5.9 ( Pass., iv B.C.); call into the lists for combat, S. El. 690 :— Pass., εἰ. εἰς τοὺς ἀγῶνας SIG 286.11 ( Milet., iv B.C.), cf. D.C. 61.20.
grow in, of eyelashes, Dsc. Eup. 1.50.
place under lock and key, ἐν θησαυρῷ PThead. 28.8 (iv A.D.).
summons, Cat. Cod. Astr. 2.195.

definition: εἰσκλύζω, f.l. for ἐκκλύζω (q.v.) in Str. 5.1.7.

children.definition: εἰσακούω, τευ ἐσέκλυον αὐδήσαντος IGRom. 1.1195 ( Memnon), cf. Q.S. 1.509.

definition: εἰσκνάω, in Pass., ἐσκνᾶσθαι· ξυρῆσαι, Hsch.

children.definition: carve upon, in Pass., LXX 3 Ki. 6.33(35) (s. v.l.).
swim into, Sch. Th. 4.26.
importation of supplies, ἡ ἐσκομιδὴ τῶν ἐπιτηδείων Th. 7.4: pl., ib. 24; bringing in, Orib. Eup. 3.7.5.

carry in, χόρτον Hes. Op. 606; guide in, A. Ag. 951:— Med., bring in for oneself, τὰ ἐκ τῶν ἀγρῶν ἐσκομίζεσθαι Th. 2.13, cf. 1.117:— Pass., ἐσκομίζεσθαι εἰς τὰ τείχη take shelter in.., Id. 2.100; ἐπειδὰν εἰσκομισθῶσιν πόλει E. HF 242; τὸν σῖτον ἐκ τῆς χώρας -κομισθῆναι IG 2.331.36; τοῖς εἰς ταὐτὸ διὰ ταὐτοῦ -ομένοις Plu. QConv. 2.699f.

children.label: II
children.definition: import into a discussion, introduce, δύο λύσεις Porph. in Cat. 139.30.
that which is brought in, and εἰσκομ-ιστέον, one must bring in, Gloss.
hang up in a place, PLond. 3.964.19 (ii/iii A.D.).
enrol, admit, εἰς τοὺς ἐφήβους POxy. 477.10 (ii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: cause to enter, πνεῦμα Iamb. Myst. 3.13, cf. PMag.Lond. 121.432; ὀυείρους μερόπεσσιν Orac. in App.Anth. 6.197: but more freq.,

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., enter into, penetrate, D.L. 1.7, Ph. 2.604, Gp. 15.6.2, Iamb. Myst. 1.8.
to be adjudged, σοφός AP 9.578 ( Leo Phil.).
entering in, penetration, τοῦ ψυχικοῦ θερμοῦ Placit. 5.25.3, cf. Plot. 4.3.9, Zos.Alch. p.205 B.: pl., κατακλίνονται ταῖς εἰ. ἀκολουθοῦντες order of admission, Ph. 2.481.

children.label: II
children.definition: enrolment, admission, PFlor. 79.9 (i A.D.), etc.
due paid on enrolment by ἔφηβοι, Ostr. 136.
knock in, πύνδακα Pherecr. 105, Thphr. Char. 30.11 (cj.).
acquire, εὔκλειαν E. Fr. 238.

wheel in, esp. in a theatre, turn a thing inwards by machinery, and so, withdraw it from the eyes of the spectators, Ar. Th. 265, cf. Luc. Lex. 8 : generally, ὄψων παρασκευὴν εἰσκυκλουμένην Ath. 6.270e : metaph., πράγματα δαίμων τις ἐσκεκύκληκεν ἐς τὴν οἰκίαν some spirit has wheeled ill luck into the house, Ar. V. 1475 :— Pass., plunge into, τοῖς τῆς ἱστορίας διηγήμασι LXX 2 Ma. 2.24:— Med., c. acc., [ἡρῷʼ ἔπη].. εἰσκυκλήσομαι Poet. in BKT 5(1)p. 84.

children.label: II
children.definition: εἰσκυκλήσας· περιελθών, Hsch.
the mechanism on which the ἐκκύκλημα turns, Poll. 4.128.
roll into, [νήσους] ὤχλισσε καὶ εἰσεκύλισε θαιάσσῃ Call. Del. 33 : Com., εἰς οἷʼ ἐμαυτὸν εἰσεκύλισα πράγματα what trouble I’ ve rolled myself into, Ar. Th. 651.
pop in, ὄμματα ἐκκύπτοντα.. κεἰσκύπτοντα, of a snail, Teucer ap. Ath. 10.455e.
overhang, ἐπὶ Γαί LXX 1 Ki. 13.18.
enter, aor. εἰσέκυρσα Ezek. Exag. 231.

definition: ἐΐσκω, poet. Verb, only pres. and impf. (exc. fut. εἴξω, τίνι [σε] εἴξομεν; Jul. Or.2.52d ) :—

children.definition: make like (cf. ἴσκω), αὐτὸν..ἤϊσκεν δέκτῃ he made him like a beggar, Od. 4.247, cf. 13.313 :— Pass., δέμας ῖσον ἐΐσκετό τινι he became like, Nonn. D. 4.72.

children.label: II
children.definition: deem like, liken, τάδε νυκτὶ ἐΐσκει Od. 20.362, cf. Il. 5.181; Ἀρτέμιδί σε..ἐΐσκω I compare thee to her, Od. 6.152, cf. Il. 3.197, Sapph. Supp. 13.5, Ibyc. Oxy. 1790.45; οὔ σε δαήμονι φωτὶ ἐΐσκω I do not deem thee like, i.e. take thee for, a wise man, Od. 8.159.
inf., deem, suppose, οὔ τί σʼ ἐΐσκομεν..ἠπεροπῆα ἔμεν 11.363, cf. Il. 13.446; ἄντα σέθεν γὰρ Ξάνθον..ἠΐσκομεν εῖναι 21.332, cf. Theoc. 25.199.
ὡς σὺ ἐΐσκεις as thou deemest, Od. 4.148. (ϝε-ϝίκ-σκω, cf. (ϝ)έ-(ϝ)οικ-α, (ϝ)ε-(ϝ)ικ-υῖα.)

burst in like a party of revellers: generally, burst in upon, τινί Luc. Lex. 9; εἰς τὴν πόλιν Aristid. Or. 51(27).30: c. acc. loci, Lyc. 1355 : metaph., εἰσεκώμασεν ὁ ἄργυρος silver came romping in, Ath. 6.231e.
shine in, Thphr. CP 2.7.4, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.929c, Plot. 5.1.2.
look upon, οἰκεῖα πάθη S. Aj. 260 (anap.), cf. Man. 4.36.

definition: εἰσμαίομαι, used by Hom. only in Ep. aor. I,

children.definition: touch to the quick, affect greatly, μάλα γάρ με θανὼν ἐσεμάσσατο θυμόν Il. 17.564; ὃς ἐμόν γε μάλιστʼ ἐσεμάσσατο θυμόν 20.425.—The pres. εἰσμαίομαι is not found, cf. ἐπιμαίομαι, εἰσματέομαι.

data.quote: μάλα γάρ με θανὼν ἐσεμάσσατο θυμόν
ὃς ἐμόν γε μάλιστʼ ἐσεμάσσατο θυμόν

children.definition: introduce evidence, Sch. E. Or. 812.
wipe upon, κόλπον ἐς εὐώδη.. ἐσεμάξατο χεῖρας, metaph., of Aphrodite imparting her charms, Theoc. 17.37.

put in the hand to feel, Hp. Art. 32 ; ἐσμασάμενος ἐς τὴν κοιλίην ib. 46; in full, τὴν χεῖρα ἔσω ἐσμάσασθαι Aret. SD 2.9.— The spelling ἐσματευόμενον Hp. Art. 38, Mul. 1.70 (v.l.), is corrupt for ἐσματεύμενον, while ἐσματτευόμενον Bacch. ap. Erot. and ἐσμάττεσθαι Gal. 18 (I).453 are Atticizing forms.
deliver corn, PEleph. 10.3 (iii B. C.), PPetr. 2p.132 ( Pass.), etc.
dwell in, Hermesian. 7.31.
go into, ἐς δὲ νέονται οὐρανόν AP 9.59 (Antip.[Thess.]).
swim into, Th. 4.26, Ael. NA 13.6.
swim into, Ael. NA 14.24.
perceive, remark, Il. 24.700, Od. 11.572, A.R. 1.1053, AP 5.266 ( Agath.).
PRyl. 162.25 (ii A.D.), cf. Sammelb. 6152.14.
collect money, Eust. 1788.2, etc. :— Pass., come in, of revenue, LXX 4 Ki. 12.4, Vett.Val. 291.27 ; to be paid, ὅπως -οδιασθῇ τὰ ὀφειλόμενα IG 5 (I).1432.7 ( Messene, i B.C. /i A.D.).
ingathering of revenue, Charis.p.577 K., Gloss.: generally, receipts, opp. ἐξοδιασμός, Arch.Pap. 1.493.

going or coming in, Suid., Zonar. : εἰσόδιοι, οἱ, visitors, Antip. ap. Stob. 4.22.103 (s.v.l.), cf. D.H. l.c. : εἰσόδιον, τό, income, revenue, PPetr. 2p.54 (iii B.C.) : pl., PHib. 1.116 ( iii B.C., - εια Pap.), Thd. Da. 11.13.

children.label: II
children.definition: εἰσόδιον, τό, introduction to a speech, Aristid. 2.321 J.
walk in, ἐς τὸ τέμενος IG 12(1).677.11 ( Ialysus).
entrance:

children.label: I
children.definition: place of entrance, entry, Od. 10.90, Hdt. 1.9, etc. ; ἐσόδους Φοίβου the entrance to his temple, E. Ion 104 (anap.); of a mountain-pass, ἡ διὰ Τρηχῖνος ἔ. ἐς τὴν Ἑλλάδα Hdt. 7.176 ; in a theatre, entrance for the Chorus, Ar. Nu. 326, Av. 296, v. Sch.; entrance-door of a court of justice, Arist. Ath. 63.2, etc. : metaph., καλῶν ἔσοδοι paths to glory, Pi. P. 5.116.

data.quote: ἡ διὰ Τρηχῖνος ἔ. ἐς τὴν Ἑλλάδα

children.label: II
children.definition: entering, entrance, εἴ. παρασχεῖν X. HG 4.4.7, etc. : pl., A. Eu. 30.
entrance into the lists to contend in the games, ἱππείαν ἔ.(cf. εἰσέρχομαι II) Pi. P. 6.50 ; also ἡ εἴ. τῆς δίκης εἰς τὸ δικαστήριον the introduction of it, Pl. Cri. 45e.
right or privilege of entrance, ἔσοδον εἶναι παρὰ βασιλέα ἄνευ ἀγγέλου Hdt. 3.118.

data.quote: ἔσοδον εἶναι παρὰ βασιλέα ἄνευ ἀγγέλου

children.definition: visit, κακῶν γυναικῶν εἴσοδοι E. Andr. 930, cf. 952, Lys. 1.20 ; of a doctor, Gal. 16.523.
study, investigation, Vett.Val. 259.7; ἀκροθιγεῖς τὰς εἰσόδους ποιήσασθαι ib. 222.11 ; also, method, ib. 108.19.

children.label: III
children.definition: that which comes in, revenue, opp. ἔξοδος, Plb. 6.13.1, cf. IG 14.423 ( Tauromenium), 5(I).1390.64 ( Andania), PPetr. 3p.151.
cause to swell, τὸ δέρμα Aret. CD 1.2.
bring in as a friend, τινὰ γάμοις Plu. Alex. 10 :— Pass., become intimate with, X. HG 5.2.25.
settle in, dub. in AP 7.320 ( Hegesipp., leg. ἐν-).
place for dwelling in, home, ἄοικος εἰ. S. Ph. 534 (dub.).

bring in as a dweller or settler, Plb. 5.100.8 :— Med. and Pass., establish oneself or be established in, ἐσοικισθέντων ἐς τοὺς Αἰθίοπας Hdt. 2.30 ; ἐς τὴν Κρήτην Id. 7.171 ; εἰς τὸ ἐργαστήριον Aeschin. 1.124 : c. acc., εἰσοικίσασθαι χώραν Plu. Sol. 7 : abs., -σαμένου τοῦ ἑσμοῦ Gp. 15.4.2; βίᾳ εἰσῳκισμένοι Aristid. Or. 26(14).29 ; οἱ ὑπὸ σοῦ εἰσοικισθησόμενοι τῷ οἴκῳ POxy. 1641.4 (i A.D.) : metaph., make oneself at home, ἡ παρανομία κατὰ σμικρὸν εἰσοικισαμένη Pl. R. 424d ; λιμὸς εἰσοικίζεται Men. 841 : c. acc., Κυδίππην κρυμὸς ἐσῳκίσατο Call. Aet. 3.1.19 [Fr. 75.19 Pf.] : c. dat., ἐμὸς αἰὼν κύμασιν αἰθυίης μᾶλλον ἐσῳκίσατο Id.Fr. 111 (178 Pfeiffer) ; but, take to oneself, give entrance to, τὴν ψυχήν Porph. Gaur. 3.5 ; γυναῖκα take to wife, Just. Nov. 18.11; ψυχῆς εἰσοικισθείσης Plot. 5.1.2.

data.quote: οἱ ὑπὸ σοῦ εἰσοικισθησόμενοι τῷ οἴκῳ

children.definition: bringing in as settler, Hld. 8.1.
build into, πλίνθους ἐς τεῖχος Th. 2.75.
to be brought in, νόμος D. 24.25.
go into, enter, c. acc., χορὸν εἰσοιχνεῦσαν Od. 6.157 ; οὐδέ μιν (sc. πάτον) εἰσοιχνεῦσι κυνηγέται 9.120 ; ὁπόσοι τὴν Διὸς αὐλὴν εἰσοιχνεῦσιν A. Pr. 122 (anap.).

definition: εἰσόκα, Dor. for sq., Bion Fr. 10.14.
εἰσόκε, before a vowel -κεν, ( εἰς ὅ κε)

children.definition: until, mostly with subj., Il. 2.332, 10.62, al. (in 3.409 ποιήσεται is Ep. for ποιήσηται), Emp. 26.7, al. : rarely with opt., Il. 15.70; in later Ep. with past tenses of ind., A.R. 1.820, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: so long as, c. subj., Il. 9.609.
slip in, Plu. Sollert. 2.972b.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ep. fut. of ( ϝ) εί- ‘rush’, ‘hasten’, δεῦρʼ εἴσεται Od. 15.213 : 3 sg. aor. εἴσατο Il. 5.538, etc. ; ἐείσατο 15.415; but sts. simply go, as εἴσῃ Od. 16.313 ; πάλιν εἴσομαι Il. 24.462, al. : c. inf. fut., ἐεισάσθην συλήσειν 15.544.
flatter, toady, in impf., Hsch.
impress upon, in Med., Chaerem. 14.15 (codd. Ath., sed leg. ἐξ-).
back: c. gen., εἰσόπιν χρόνου hereafter, A. Supp. 617.
in time to come, hereafter, h.Ven. 104, S. Ph. 1104 (lyr.), Rhian. 66.

children.label: II
children.definition: backwards, Opp. C. 4.362, Q.S. 1.243, al.
visible, βλεφάροις θνατῶν ἔσ. Simon. 58.4, cf. Hdt. 2.138, Antipho Soph. 6.
reflect like a glass, Plu. QConv. 2.696a :— Med., look at oneself in a glass, ib. Coniug. 141c, Iamb. Protr. 21.κδ; see as in a glass, ἀμυδρῶς τὴν πάλαι λαμπρότητα Lyd. Mag. 3.1.
seen in a mirror, εἰκόνες Plu. Fac.lun. 2.920f.
AP 6.307 ( Phanias).

definition: εἰσόπτρισμα, ατος, τό, = sq., Secund. Sent. 4.

children.definition: reflection as in a mirror, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.936e.
like a mirror or reflection, Placit. 2.20.12.

definition: εἴσοπτρον (so CPR 21.20 (iii A.D.)), mostly in the form ἔσοπτρον, τό, ( ὄψομαι)

children.definition: looking-glass, mirror, Pi. N. 7.14, J. AJ 12.2.9, Plu. Profect. 2.85b, Coniug. 139f, Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 37.26, Anacreont. 6.3.

definition: εἰσοράω, Ep. part. εἰσορόων, inf. Med. εἰσοράασθαι: fut. εἰσόψομαι: aor. εἰσεῖδον, Ep. inf. - ιδέειν:—

children.definition: look into, look upon, behold, common in Poets, Od. 4.142, al., Sapph. Supp. 13.3, etc., but rare in Prose (as X. Cyr. 5.1.16, Pl. Grg. 526c); ἐσορᾶν καλός Pi. O. 8.19; ἐλεινὸς εἰσορᾶν A. Pr. 248; ἐσ. τὴν νέα Hdt. 8.92:— Med. in same sense, freq. in Hom., εἰσοράασθε ἵππους Il. 23.495 : mostly in inf., οὗ..ὀξύτατον.. φάος εἰσοράασθαι whose eye is quickest to discern, 14.345; ὥς τε.. ἀθάνατος ἰνδάλλεται εἰσοράασθαι he is like an immortal to behold, Od. 3.246; μείζονες εἰσοράασθαι 10.396, cf. 24.252 : aor. εἰσειδόμην, imper. ἐσίδεσθʼ A. Pr. 141 (anap.); εἰσιδόμαν ib. 427 (lyr.):— Pass., ὅσσον.. ἠελίοιο μεσσηγὺς δύσιές τε καὶ ἀντολαὶ εἰσορόωνται A.R. 1.85.

data.quote: ὅσσον.. ἠελίοιο μεσσηγὺς δύσιές τε καὶ ἀντολαὶ εἰσορόωνται

children.label: b
children.definition: part., εἰσορῶ τινὰ στείχοντα E. Hipp. 51; πόλιν..μοι ξυνοῦσαν εὔνουν S. OC 772: parenthetic, ὡς ἕρποντος (εἰσορᾶς) ἐμοῦ since I (thou seest) am coming, Id. Tr. 394 (s.v.l.).

look upon with admiration, πάντες δὲ θεοὺς ὣς εἰσορόωσι Il. 12.312; μιν..θεὸν ὣς εἰσορόωντες Od. 7.71; simply, σε μᾶλλον Ἀχαιοὶ εἰσορόωσιν.. 20.166: hence, pay regard to, respect, πλοῦτον ἢ εὐγένειαν E. El. 1097: with a Prep., ἐσορῶντες ἐς τὴν μαντικήν Hdt. 4.68: generally, look at or gaze upon steadily, A. Pers. 111 (lyr.), E. Med. 264.
look on with the mindʼs eye, perceive, οὐκ εἰσορᾷς; S. El. 997, cf. 611; εἰ.ὡς.. Id. Ph. 501.
visit, θεοὶ γὰρ εὖ μὲν ὀψὲ δʼ εἰσορῶσι Id. OC 1536, cf. 1370.

data.quote: θεοὶ γὰρ εὖ μὲν ὀψὲ δʼ εἰσορῶσι

children.definition: μή, take care lest.., Id. El. 584.
bring forcibly into, ῥυθμὸν Μούσῃ AP 7.707 ( Diosc.):— Pass., rush into, c. acc., θάλαμον εἰσορμωμένην S. Tr. 913:—intr. in Act., εἰσορμᾶν πρὸς Ἱππότας Plu. Amat.narr. 2.775a.
bring into port:— Pass., run into port, of seafaring men, εἰσορμισθέντας X. Vect. 3.1: aor. Med., εἰς τὸν ποταμὸν εἰσωρμίσαντο Plu. Cim. 12.
rush in, v.l. in Pi. O. 8.40.

definition: ἔϊσος, η, ον [ῑ], Ep. form of ἶσος,

children.definition: alike, equal, Hom., only fem. sg. and pl., always in set phrases (exc. [ ἵππους]..σταφύλῃ ἐπὶ νῶτον ἐΐσας equal in height, Il. 2.765):

equal, i.e. equally shared, of which each partakes alike, esp. of sacrificial feasts or of meals given to a stranger (for on other occasions the greatest men had the best portions), δαιτὸς ἐΐσης 1.468, al.
even or well-balanced, νηὸς ἐΐσης 15.729; νῆες ἐῗσαι Od. 5.175, al.
evenly balanced, ἀσπίδα πάντοσʼ ἐΐσην Il. 12.294, 13.157, 160, etc.
even, well-balanced, φρένας ἔνδον ἐΐσας Od. 11.337, 14.178.
against the time when, Od. 2.99, al.

definition: εἰσοφάγος or εἰσωφάγος [ ᾶ], etym. of οἰσοφάγος, Gal. 19.125, Pall. in Hp. 2.192 D.

children.definition: conduct into, Hld. 9.3.
hollow, recess, opp. ἐξοχή, Str. 2.5.22 (pl.), cf. 12.2.4 (pl.); of intaglios, κατʼ εἰσοχήν, opp. κατʼ ἐξοχήν, Stoic. 1.108.
spectacle, E. El. 1085 codd.

definition: εἰσόψομαι, fut. of εἰσοράω, Ep. ἐς- Il. 5.212, 24.206.

children.definition: burst or rush in, S. OT 1252, Xenarch. 1.3, J. BJ 4.1.9: c. acc. loci, κρυπτὸν λόχον εἰσπαίσας E. Rh. 560 (lyr.).
receive (?), Hierocl. p.29A.
slide gently into, Ph. 2.432.

send in, σύ μʼ ἐσπέμπεις δόμους E. HF 850, cf. Th. 4.16; γράμματα πρὸς βασιλέα Id. 1.137; suborn agents, S. OT 705, And. 2.4; ῥήτορας send them into court, instruct them, Pl. Euthd. 305b; τῷ μὴ καλῷ θάρρει τὸν κάλλιστον φόβον pit against.., Id. Lg. 671d.
pass over into, Χαλκίδα τʼ εἰσεπέρησα Hes. Op. 655: abs., Orph. A. 442.

definition: εἰσπέτομαι, fut. - πτήσομαι: aor. εἰσεπτόμην Ar. (v. infr.), but 3 sg. - έπτατο Il. 21.494; part. ἐσπτόμενοι D.C. 45.17: also in Act. form -έπτην Ath. 9.395a, Plu. Cohib. 2.461e, etc. : aor. Pass. in med. sense, -πετασθῆναι Arist. HA 624b6:—

children.definition: fly into, fly in, c.acc., κοίλην εἰσέπτατο πέτρην Il. l.c. ; ἐς τὸν ἀέρα Ar. Av. 1173; of weapons, ἐς τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς καὶ πρὸς τὰς χεῖρας D.C. 40.22: metaph. of reports, Hdt. 9.100, 101.

data.quote: ἐς τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς καὶ πρὸς τὰς χεῖρας

children.definition: leap in, ἐς τὰς λίμνας Hdt. 4.132; εἰς τὸν πηλόν X. An. 1.5.8.
burst in, εἰσπηδήσας πρός με νύκτωρ Μειδίας Test. ap. D. 21.22; εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν ib. 78, cf. PHal. 1.169 (iii B.C.); εἰς τὰ συνέδρια Hell.Oxy. 10.2: abs., rush in, Men. Sam. 219, Act.Ap. 16.29.
house-breaker, Gloss.

fall into, generally with a notion of violence, rush or burst in, ἐς τὰς πόλιας Hdt. 5.15; ἐς τὰς νέας Id. 8.56; ἐς οἴκημα Th. 2.4, etc.; of the sea, Id. 4.24 : poet. c. dat., ἐσπίπτει δόμοις E. Ion 1196.

fall into, ἐς χωρίον Th. 1.106; ἐς χαράδρας Id. 3.98, etc.; ἐσ. ἐς εἱρκτήν to be thrown into prison, Id. 1.131: in Poets, c.acc., ἐσπεσοῦσα δικτύων βρόχους E. Or. 1315; ὄχλον γὰρ ἐσπεσεῖν ᾐσχυνόμην to go into the crowd, Id. Hel. 415; ἐσ. πέπλους seek shelter within my robes, Id. Tr. 1181; πτέρυγας ἐσπίτνων ἐμάς ib. 751; κτύπου κέλευθον ἐσπεσόντος a noise having come into the street, Id. Or. 1312.
fall into a certain condition, δούλειον ἦμαρ εἰ. Id. Andr. 99; ξυμφοράν ib. 983; γῆρας Id. Ion 700: in Th. 4.4 ἐνέπεσε shd. be read.

children.label: II
children.definition: make an onset, attack, Hdt. 1.63, S. Aj. 55; ἐ. ἐς τὸν πεζόν Hdt. 4.128; ἐς τοὺς ἀγρούς Th. 2.22; ἐπὶ τὰς θύρας ‘besiege the door’, Plu. Oth. 17.

children.label: III
children.definition: come in, of payments, Meyer Ostr. 82.4 (iv A.D.).

definition: εἰσπίτνω, poet. form of εἰσπίπτω, E. Tr. 751.

sail into, enter, ἐς τὰ στενά Th. 2.86, cf. 89, etc.: poet. c. acc., E. IT 1389: c. acc. et dat., ὑμέναιον δόμοις εἰσέπλευσας S. OT 423.

sail in, ἐπʼ ἀριστερὰ ἐσπλέοντι as one sails in, Hdt. 6.33; στόμα ναυσὶ ταῖς μεγίσταις ἱκανὸν εἰσπλεῖν Pl. Criti. 115d; εἰσπλέοντας ἐκπλέοντάς τε Pl.Com. 183; Μεγαρεῦσι μηδὲν ἐσπλεῖν Th. 3.51, cf. X. HG 2.4.29; of corn, to be imported, D. 20.31.

data.quote: στόμα ναυσὶ ταῖς μεγίσταις ἱκανὸν εἰσπλεῖν

sailing in of ships, βιάσασθαι τὸν ἔσ. Th. 7.22, cf. 24 (pl.), X. HG 2.2.9.
right of entry, εἶναι αὐτῷ εἴ. καὶ ἔκπλουν αὐτοῖς εἶναι καὶ ἐν πολέμῳ καὶ ἐν εἰρήνῃ IG 12(7).8 (Amorgos), etc.

children.definition: entrance of a harbour, Th. 4.8 (pl.); λιμὴν στενόν τινα ἔχων εἴ. Pl. Ti. 25a.
inhalation, opp. ἔκπνευσις, Arist. Ph. 243b26.
one must inhale, Gal. 6.359.
inhale, opp. ἀναπνέω, ἐκπνέω, Arist. Resp. 472b3, Pr. 887b17.
inhale, ἀέρα Hld. 2.35 ; εὐοσμίας Aristaenet. 1.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: breathe upon, με αὔρα τις εἰσέπνευσε Ar. Ra. 314 ( Pass., ἀνέμῳ ἐσπνεῖσθαι Philostr. VA 2.8) ; τινί Ael. VH 3.12 (a Lacedaemonian phrase for inspire with love); ἐς τὴν ἀναπνοήν Aret. SA 1.7.
lover (cf. foreg. II), Call. Fr. 169, Theoc. 12.13.
inspiration, inhalation, opp. ἐκπνοή, Arist. Resp. 471a8, cf. Str. 3.5.7; μιᾷ ἐσπνοῇ θνῄσκουσι Aret. SA 1.7.
inhaling, Hp. Epid. 6.6.1.

give in adoption, ὑόν τινι Pl. Lg. 878a ; τὸν παῖδα εἰς τὸν οῖκόν τινος D. 43.15; τοὺς σφετέρους παῖδας εἰς ἑτέρους οἴκους εἰσποιοῦσιν Is. 10.17 (but the same phrase is used of a father who begets, Id. 6.22); εἰ. τινὰ εἰς τὰ χρήματά τινος make him heir to the property, Id. 10.12, cf. 16, 17, etc.; εἰ. σαυτὸν Ἄμμωνι, of Alexander, Plu. Alex. 50 : metaph., [ ἡ παντάρβη] πᾶν τὸ ἐγγὺς ἐσποιεῖ αὑτῇ attracts, Philostr. VA 3.46:— Med., adopt as oneʼs son, D. 44.34, Ph. 2.86, D.C. 44.5 :— Pass., εἰσποιηθῆναι πρός τινα to be adopted into his family, D. 44.27; ἐπὶ τὸ ὄνομά τινος ib. 36.

data.quote: τὸν παῖδα εἰς τὸν οῖκόν τινος
τοὺς σφετέρους παῖδας εἰς ἑτέρους οἴκους εἰσποιοῦσιν

children.definition: εἰ. τινὰς εἰς λῃτουργίαν bring new persons into the public service, Id. 20.19,20 ; τῶν πραττομένων εἰσεποίει κοινωνὸν αὑτόν forced himself in as partaker, Din. 1.32; εἰ. ἐγκώμιον εἰς τὴν ἱστορίαν introduce panegyric into history, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 9; εἰ. ἑαυτὸν εἰς δύναμίν τινος thrust himself into anotherʼs authority, Plu. Pomp. 16; εἰ. Ἡσιόδῳ Θεογονίαν father it on him, Paus. 9.27.2.
τὸ τάχος [τὴν τίγριν] ἐσ. τοῖς ἀνέμοις adopts into the family of winds, i.e. makes it as swift as the winds, Philostr. VA 3.48.

adoption, Is. 10.14, Plu. Oth. 16, etc.
introduction, Suid.

supply, v.l. in Isoc. 5.121.
exactor, taskmaster, Aq. Ex. 5.13.
chargeable, BGU 486.13 (ii A.D.).
Hsch.

children.definition: levy of recruits, Wilcken Chr. 469.4 (iv A.D.).

get in or exact, φόρον IG 1(2).65.16, cf. 2(2).1172.18, Pl. Lg. 949d, Plb. 13.7.3, Plu. Stoic.rep. 2.1044a : c.acc. pers., τοὺς ὑπερημέρους D. 21.11, cf. 24.13; οὐκ εἰσέπραξε τὸν δῆμον did not charge the people [with it], Decr. ap. D. 18.115: c. dupl. acc., τοσοῦτον πλῆθος χρημάτων εἰ. τοὺς συμμάχους Isoc. 5.146; προσήκει ὑμᾶς τοῦτον εἰσπρᾶξαί μοι τὰ ἀναλώματα D. 50.67:— Med., exact for oneself, have paid one, κακὸν δίκαιον εἰσεπράξατο E. IT 559; Med. is freq. interchangeable with Act., D. 21.155: so in pf. Pass., πικρῶς εἰσπράττειν με, ὥσπερ καὶ παρὰ τῶν ἄλλων εἰσπέπρακται Id. 35.44; also εἰ. τιμωρίαν exact vengeance, Jul. Or. 2.58a:— Pass., of the money to be exacted, D. 19.21, IG 2.814a A 24; of persons, have money exacted from one, have to pay it, D. 33.24.

data.quote: τοσοῦτον πλῆθος χρημάτων εἰ. τοὺς συμμάχους

Lyc. 30 ; τὸ πάθος εἰσερρύη slipped in, Pl. Phdr. 262b ; ἐπιστῆμαι εἰσρέουσι Id. Phlb. 62c ; ἁμάρτημα εἰσρεῖ D.H. Rh. 10.17 ; πόθος εἰσερρύη πάντας εὐνομίας Plu. Num. 20.
irrumpo, Dosith. p.434K.
influx, Ael. NA 1.53, Marcian. Peripl. 1.1 ; τοῦ ἀέρος Porph. Gaur. 3.3.
ὑδάτων POxy. 1409.19 (iii A.D.).

εἴσρυσις, εως, ἡ, = foreg., IG ΙΙ(2).199 A 55 ( Delos, iii B.C.).

definition: εἰστείχω (for εἰσστ-), = εἰσέρχομαι, Schwyzer 633.1, al. ( Lesbos).

put on board ship, πάντα ἐσθέντες (sc. ἐς τὰς πεντηκοντέρους) Id. 1.164 :— Med., ἐσθέμενοι τέκνα καὶ γυναῖκας ibid., cf. 4.179, E. Hel. 1566, X. HG 1.6.20 ; to take, ἐς φορεῖον App. BC 4.19.
Pass., to be entered, of a judgement in court, PPetr. 3p.39 (iii B.C.).

shoot arrows at, Hdt. 9.49.

children.definition: carry in, εἴσω Od. 7.6 ; ἐσ. ἀγγελίας Hdt. 1.114 ; ἐς τὠυτὸ ἐσ. Id. 9.70 ; τινὰ εἰς τὸ λογιστήριον PAmh. 2.77.22 (ii A.D.).

bring in, contribute, τῖμον Archil. l.c.; χρήματα X. Hier. 9.7, Plu. Publ. 12; εἰ. τινὶ ἔρανον Pl. Smp. 177c, cf. X. Cyr. 7.1.12 ; at Athens, etc., pay the property-tax (v. εἰσφορά II), ἐσ. ἐσφοράν Th. 3.19, etc. ; εἰσφοράς Antipho 2.2.12, Lys. 18.7 : and abs., εἰ. εἰς τὴν πόλιν D. 27.36 ; εἰ. ἀφʼ ὑπαρχούσης οὐσίας Id. 21.157.
bring in or upon, πένθος δόμοις E. Ba. 367 ; νόσον καινὴν γυναιξί ib. 353 ; πόλεμον Ἑλλήνων χθονί Id. Hel. 38 ; δειλίαν ἐσφέρει τοῖς ἀλκίμοισι brings cowardice into the brave, Id. Supp. 540.

introduce, καινὰ δαιμόνια X. Mem. 1.1.2 ; ψεῦδος Plb. 2.58.12 ; esp. of political measures, bring forward, propose, γνώμην Hdt. 3.80 ; γνώμην ἐς τὸν δῆμον Th. 8.67 ; εἰ. νόμον,=Lat. legem rogare, D. 23.218, 24.19; ψηφίσματα IG 2(2).1329.10 ; τιμάς ib. 1343.29 : abs., ἐσ. ἐς τὰς βουλὰς περί τινος Th. 5.38 ; εἰς τοὺς νομοφύλακας Pl. Lg. 772c ; τὴν δὲ βουλὴν εἰσενεγκεῖν, ὅτῳ τρόπῳ.. X. HG 1.7.7 :— Pass., τὰ εἰσφερόμενα [ψηφίσματα] Arist. Pol. 1298b33.

data.quote: ἐσ. ἐς τὰς βουλὰς περί τινος
τὴν δὲ βουλὴν εἰσενεγκεῖν, ὅτῳ τρόπῳ..

bring in for oneself, τὰ ἐκ τῶν ἀγρῶν ἐς τὸ τεῖχος Hdt. 5.34, cf. Th. 5.115 :—so in Pass., σῖτον ἐσενηνεῖχθαι or -έχθαι Hdt. 9.41.

Hel. 664 (lyr.) ; νʼ μνᾶς εἰς τὸν οἶκον εἰσενηνεγμένη having brought 50 minae as a dowry into the family, D. 27.4, cf. 41.4 ; προῖκα εἰσενεγκαμένῃ Thphr. Char. 22.10.

Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.293, IG 2(2).1343.23, Inscr.Prien. 111.126 (i B.C.), D.S. 1.84 ; ἀνδρείαν Onos. 4.2; θάρσος J. AJ 18.8.5 ; ἰσχύν ib. 17.5.6 ; φιλονεικίαν Ael. VH 12.64.
eat, Hp. VM 3, Ant.Lib. 11.1 ; drink water, Arist. GA 767a32.

definition: εἴσφλασις, ιος, ἡ, Ion. for ἔσθλ-,

inroad, invasion, τῶν Περσῶν Agath. 4.19 (pl.).

definition: εἴσω, ἔσω, used by Ep., Lyr., and Trag. Poets acc. as a spondee or iambus is required ; ἔσω (as ἐς for εἰς) prevailed in Ion. and old Att. Prose ; but in other Prose and in Com. εἴσω was the only form admitted, whereas ἔσωθεν with the Comp. and Sup. ἐσώτερος, ἐσώτατος, ἐσωτέρω, ἐσωτάτω, seem to have been the only forms in use :— Adv. of εἰς, ἐς,

children.definition: to within, into : abs., μή πού τις ἐπαγγείλῃσι καὶ εἴσω lest some one may carry the news into the house, Od. 4.775, cf. Hdt. 1.111, al.; so εἴπατε δʼ εἴσω Od. 3.427 ; also εἴσω δʼ ἀσπίδʼ ἔαξε he brake it through to the inside, Il. 7.270 ; so ὀστέα δʼ εἴσω ἔθλασεν Od. 18.96 ; εἴσω ἐπιγράψαι τέρενα χρόα Il. 13.553 ; ἐσσύμενοι εἴσω Pi. P. 4.135 ; εἴσω κομίζου A. Ag. 1035 ; πέπληγμαι..ἔσω ib. 1343 ; εἴσω.. δεῦρʼ εἴσιθʼ Ar. Pl. 231 ; ἡγεῖσθαι εἴσω, φεύγειν εἴσω, X. Cyr. 2.3.21, 7.5.26 ; παρακαλέσαι εἴσω Id. An. 1.6.5.

children.definition: Hom. prefers the acc., δῦναι δόμον Ἄϊδος εἴσω Il. 3.322 ; πέρησε δʼ ἄρʼ ὀστέον εἴσω αἰχμή 6.10, etc. ; ἡγήσατο.. Ἴλιον εἴσω 1.71, etc. ; more rarely with gen., κατελθόντʼ Ἄϊδος εἴσω 6.284, cf. 22.425 ; ἐβήσετο δώματος εἴσω Od. 7.135, cf. 8.290 ; so in Prose and Trag., Κύκλωπος ἔσω βλεφάρων ὤσας E. Cyc. 485 ; it generally follows its case, but precedes in Il. 21.125, 24.155, Od. 8.290.

Aj. 105 ; οὔτε πύργος οὔτε ναῦς ἔρημος ἀνδρῶν μὴ ξυνοικούντων ἔσω Id. OT 57 ; τὸ ἔσω μέτωπον the inner front, Th. 3.21 ; τὰ εἴσω νενοσηκότα σώματα Pl. R. 407d ; εἴσω τὴν χεῖρα ἔχειν ἀναβεβλημένον D. 19.251.

Or. 1531 ; εἴσω τῶν ὅπλων within the heavy-armed troops, i.e. encircled by them, X. An. 3.3.7, 3.4.26 ; εἴσω τῶν ὀρέων within, i.e. on this side of, the mountains, ib. 1.2.21 ; ἔσω τούτων inside of these people, i.e. farther inland, Th. 2.100 ; εἴσω βέλους within bow-shot, Arr. An. 1.6.8 ; τὰ δένδρα τῆς ὁδοῦ ποιεῖν εἴσω, i.e. inside, i.e. by the side of, the road, D. 55.22 ; εἴσω τῆς εἰρωνείας ἀφικνεῖσθαι Id. Prooem. 14 ; πάντα εἴσω τῆς συμφορᾶς Lib. Or. 61.18.

thrust into, τι ἐς τὸ ἔσω μέρος Hp. Art. 34 ; χεῖρα Aret. SD 2.1 ; ἔνδον τὰς στάλικας Lib. Descr. 10.4 :— Med., force oneself into, press in, X. An. 5.2.18 ; εἰς τοὺς ὄχλους Porph. Hist.Phil.Fr. 12.
aspect, Opp. H. 4.358.
within, i.e. between (perh. connected with ὀπή), εἰσωποὶ δʼ ἐγένοντο νεῶν Il. 15.653 : abs., in harbour, A.R. 2.751.
ὤψ) visible, Arat. 79, 122.
inward thrust, of spinal curvature, Gal. 14.796.
tomb, in pl., CIG 2824 ( Aphrodisias), JHS 20.76 ( Caria). (Prob. from ὠθέω, cf. ὑπώστη.)

definition: εἶτα, Ion. εἶτεν (q.v., cf. ἔπειτα, -εν), Adv., used to denote the Sequence of one act or state upon another :

children.label: I
children.definition: then, next, πρῶτα μέν.., εἶτα.. S. El. 262, cf. Pl. Phdr. 251a, etc. ; soon, presently, S. OT 452 ; εἶτα τί τοῦτο; well, what then? Ar. Nu. 347, Pl. Prt. 309a ; εἶτα.. τότε then.. after that, Ar. Eq. 1036 codd. (fort. τόδε) : freq. repeated, sts. alternating with ἔπειτα, then.., next.., then.., after that.., etc., Men. 154, etc. ; with πάλιν, SIG 1171 ; εἶτʼ οὖν also, Sch. Pi. O. 7.68.

part., expressing surprise or incongruity, and then, and yet, μή μοι προτείνων κέρδος εἶτʼ ἀποστέρει A. Pr. 777 ; ἆρα κλύουσα, μῆτερ, εἶτʼ ἔρξεις κακῶς ; E. El. 1058, cf. S. El. 53, Aj. 468, 1092, 1094, X. An. 1.2.25, etc. ; cf. ἔπειτα I.3.

data.quote: μή μοι προτείνων κέρδος εἶτʼ ἀποστέρει
ἆρα κλύουσα, μῆτερ, εἶτʼ ἔρξεις κακῶς ;

children.label: II
children.definition: and so, therefore, accordingly ; esp. in questions or exclamations to express surprise, indignation, contempt, sarcasm, and the like, and then..? and so..? κᾆτʼ οὐ δέχονται λιτάς ; S. Ant. 1019, cf. OC 418 ; εἶτʼ ἐγὼ μὲν οὐ φρονῶ ; E. Andr. 666 ; κᾆτα ποῦʼ στιν ἡ δίκη; Id. Ph. 548 ; εἶτʼ ἐσίγας, Πλοῦτος ὤν ; Ar. Pl. 79 ; εἶτʼ ἄνδρα τῶν αὑτοῦ τι χρὴ προϊέναι ; Id. Nu. 1214 ; εἶτʼ οὐκ αἰσχύνεσθε ; D. 1.24, cf. Pl. Ap. 28b ; οὐκ οἴεσθε δεῖν χρήματα εἰσφέρειν, εἶτα θαυμάζετε.. ; D. 21.203 ; εἶτʼ οὐκ ἐπῳδούς φασιν ἰσχύειν τινές ; Antiph. 217.15 ; εἶτʼ οὐ περίεργόν ἐστιν ἄνθρωπος φυτόν ; Alex. 141.1, etc.

data.quote: εἶτʼ ἄνδρα τῶν αὑτοῦ τι χρὴ προϊέναι ;
οὐκ οἴεσθε δεῖν χρήματα εἰσφέρειν, εἶτα θαυμάζετε.. ;
εἶτʼ οὐκ ἐπῳδούς φασιν ἰσχύειν τινές ;
εἶτʼ οὐ περίεργόν ἐστιν ἄνθρωπος φυτόν ;

definition: εἷται, 3 sg. pf. Pass. of ἕννυμι, Od. 11.191.
εἴτε, Dor. αἴτε, generally doubled, εἴτε..εἴτε..,

children.definition: sive..sive.., either..or.., whether..or.., so that two cases are put as equally possible or equivalent ; thrice repeated, S. El. 606 ; εἴτʼ οὖν.., εἴτε.. Id. OT 1049 ; εἴτʼ οὖν.., εἴτε καί.. A. Ag. 843 ; εἴτʼ οὖν.., εἴτʼ οὖν.. Id. Ch. 683 ; εἴτε.., εἴτʼ ἄρʼ οὖν.. S. Ph. 345 ; εἴτε.., εἴτʼ αὖ.. Pl. Phlb. 34b ; εἴτε καί.., εἴτε καί.. Id. R. 471d : with Substantives, τὴν εἴθʼ ἡδονὴν εἴτε ἀπονίαν ἢ εὐστάθειαν Plu. Suav. 2.1089d : the first εἴτε is sts. omitted in Poets, ξεῖνος, αἴτʼ ὦν ἀστός Pi. P. 4.78 ; αἰνεῖν, εἴτε με ψέγειν θέλεις A. Ag. 1403 ; μύραινά γʼ, εἴτʼ ἔχιδνʼ ἔφυ Id. Ch. 1002 ; λόγοισιν, εἴτʼ ἔργοισιν S. OT 517, cf. Tr. 236 ; and even in Prose, πόλις, εἴτε ἰδιῶται Pl. Lg. 864a, cf. 907d, Sph. 224e : the first εἴτε is sts. replaced by εἰ, as εἰ..εἴτε.., Lat. utrum..an.., v.l. in Hdt. 3.35 ; εἰ.. εἴτε καί.. A. Ch. 768 ; εἰ..εἴτε μή Id. Eu. 468 ; εἰ μὲν.., εἴτε καὶ μή.. X. Cyr. 2.1.7 ; sts. ἤ ( ἠὲ καί.. v.l. in Il. 2.349) stands for the second εἴτε, E. El. 896, Pl. Phdr. 277d, IG 1.40.5 ; or for the first, S. Aj. 178 (lyr.), E. Alc. 115 (lyr.) ; εἴτε.. εἴτε.., c. subj. (cf. εἰ), v.l. in Archyt. ap Stob. 3.1.105.

data.quote: τὴν εἴθʼ ἡδονὴν εἴτε ἀπονίαν ἢ εὐστάθειαν

children.label: II
children.definition: Od. 3.90, etc. ; σκοπεῖτε εἴτʼ ὀρθῶς λογίζομαι ταῦτʼ εἴτε μή D. 15.11.

data.quote: σκοπεῖτε εἴτʼ ὀρθῶς λογίζομαι ταῦτʼ εἴτε μή

children.definition: 2 pl. pres. opt. of εἰμί ( sum), Od. 21.195.
SIG 57.29 ( Milet., v B.C.), Scymn. 330, al., Ev.Marc. 4.28, IG 5(1).1390.31 ( Andania), 7.3073.150 (Lebad.) : condemned by Phryn. 101 ; Ion. acc. to Ael.Dion. ap. Eust. 1158.38.

definition: εἰτισκαί πηγή, παρὰ τῶς Κλειτῶς (prob. τοῖς Κλειτορίοις), Hsch.
εἴχεται οἴχεται, Hsch. εἰχόμενος· κατεχόμενος, Id.

children.definition: Hdn. Philet. p.446P.
in customary wise, S. El. 1456, Aristid. Or. 51(27).48, etc.; εἰ. ἔλεξεν in his usual manner, Pl. Smp. 218d.

definition: ἐκ, before a vowel ἐξ, also ἐξ τῳ ϝοίκῳ Inscr.Cypr. 135.5 H., in Att. Inscrr. before ς ξ ζ ρ and less freq. λ ; ἐγ- in Inscrr. before β γ δ λ μ ν ; Cret. and Boeot. ἐς Leg.Gort. 2.49, Corinn. Supp. 2.67 ; ἐχ freq. in Att. Inscrr. before χ φ θ (and in early Inscrr. before σ, IG 1(2).304.20) ; also ἐ Ναυπάκτω ib. 9(1).334.8 ( Locr.) ; ( ἐτ is for ἐπὶ in ib. 9(2).517.14 (Thess.))

children.definition: Arc., c. dat., Inscr.Cypr. 135.5 H. ( Idalium), (in form ἐς) IG 5(2).6.49 ( Tegea, iv B.C.)) :—radical sense, from out of, freq. also simply, from.

out of, forth from, ἐκ Πύλου ἐλθὼν τηλόθεν ἐξ ἀπίης γαίης Il. 1.269, cf. Pl. Prt. 321c, etc. ; μάχης ἔκ Il. 17.207 ; ἂψ ἐκ δυσμενέων ἀνδρῶν 24.288 ; ἐξ ὀχέων, ἐξ ἕδρης, 3.29, 19.77 ; φεύγειν ἐκ πολέμοιο 7.119 ; ἐκ τῶν πολεμίων ἐλθεῖν X. Cyr. 6.2.9 ; ἐκ χειρῶν γέρας εἵλετο Il. 9.344, cf. S. Ph. 1287 (but ἐκ χειρὸς βάλλειν or παίειν to strike with a spear in the hand, opp. ἀντιτοξεύειν or ἀκοντίζειν, X. An. 3.3.15, Cyr. 4.3.16 ; ἐκ χειρὸς τὴν μάχην ποιεῖσθαι ib. 6.2.16, cf. 6.3.24, etc.) ; ἐκ χρυσῶν φιαλῶν πίνειν ib. 5.3.3 ; ἐξ ἀγορᾶς ὠνεῖσθαι Pl.Com. 190.

data.quote: ἐκ Πύλου ἐλθὼν τηλόθεν ἐξ ἀπίης γαίης

children.definition: ἐκ θυμοῦ φίλεον I loved her from my heart, with all my heart, Il. 9.343 ; ἐκ τῆς ψυχῆς ἀσπάσασθαι X. Oec. 10.4 ; μέγαν ἐκ θυμοῦ κλάζοντες Ἄρη A. Ag. 48 (anap.) ; δακρυχέων ἐκ φρενός Id. Th. 919 (anap.) ; οὐδὲν ἐκ σαυτῆς λέγεις S. El. 344 ; ἐξ εὐμενῶν στέρνων δέχεσθαι receive with kindly heart, Id. OC 486 ; ἐξ ὀμμάτων ὀρθῶν δὲ κἀξ ὀρθῆς φρενός Id. OT 528 ; ὀρθὸς ἐξ ὀρθῶν δίφρων with chariot still upright, Id. El. 742 ; ἐξ ἀκινήτου ποδός Id. Tr. 875 ; ἐξ ἑνὸς ποδός Id. Ph. 91.

data.quote: ἐξ ὀμμάτων ὀρθῶν δὲ κἀξ ὀρθῆς φρενός

children.definition: δέχεται κακὸν ἐκ κακοῦ one evil comes from (or after) another, Il. 19.290 ; ἐκ φόβου φόβον τρέφω S. Tr. 28 ; πόλιν ἐκ πόλεως ἀμείβειν, ἀλλάττειν, Pl. Sph. 224b, Plt. 289e ; λόγον ἐκ λόγου λέγειν D. 18.313 ; πόρους ἐκ πόρων ὑπισχνούμενοι Alciphr. 1.8 ; ἀπαλλάττειν τινὰ ἐκ γόων S. El. 291 ; ἐκ κακῶν πεφευγέναι Id. Ant. 437 : hence, instead of, τυφλὸς ἐκ δεδορκότος Id. OT 454 ; λευκὴν..ἐκ μελαίνης ἀμφιβάλλομαι τρίχα Id. Ant. 1093 ; ἐλεύθερος ἐκ δούλου καὶ πλούσιος ἐκ πτωχοῦ γεγονώς D. 18.131, cf. X. An. 7.7.28, etc.

data.quote: ἐλεύθερος ἐκ δούλου καὶ πλούσιος ἐκ πτωχοῦ γεγονώς

children.definition: from a number, ἐκ πολέων πίσυρες four out of many, Il. 15.680 ; μοῦνος ἐξ ἁπάντων σωθῆναι Hdt. 5.87 ; εἶναι ἐκ τῶν δυναμένων to be one of the wealthy, Pl. Grg. 525e ; ἐμοὶ ἐκ πασέων Ζεὺς ἄλγεʼ ἔδωκεν to me out of ( i.e. above) all, Il. 18.431, cf. 432 ; ἐκ πάντων μάλιστα 4.96, cf. S. Ant. 1137 (lyr.), etc. ; redundant, εἷς τῶν ἐκ τῶν φίλων σου LXX Jd. 15.2.

data.quote: εἷς τῶν ἐκ τῶν φίλων σου

children.definition: outside of, beyond, chiefly in early writers, ἐκ βελέων out of shot, Il. 14.130, etc. ; ἐκ καπνοῦ out of the smoke, Od. 19.7 ; ἐκ πατρίδος banished from oneʼs country, 15.272 ; ἐκ μεσου κατῆστο sat down apart from the company, Hdt. 3.83 ; ἐξ ἠθέων τὸν ἥλιον ἀνατεῖλαι out of its accustomed quarters, Id. 2.142; ἐξ ὀφθαλμῶν out of sight, Id. 5.24 ; ἐξ ὁδοῦ out of the road, S. OC 113.

on, in, δαῖέ οἱ ἐκ κόρυθος..πῦρ lighted a fire from ( i.e. on) his helmet, Il. 5.4 ; ἐκ ποταμοῦ χρόα νίζετο washed his body in the river ( with water from the river), Od. 6.224 : freq. with Verbs signifying hang or fasten, σειρήν..ἐξ οὐρανόθεν κρεμάσαντες having hung a chain from heaven, Il. 8.19 ; ἐκ πασσαλόφι κρέμασεν φόρμιγγα he hung his lyre from ( i.e. on) the peg, Od. 8.67 ; ἀνάπτεσθαι ἔκ τινος fasten from i.e. upon) a thing, 12.51 ; μαχαίρας εἶχον ἐξ ἀργυρέων τελαμώνων Il. 18.598 ; πρισθεὶς ἐξ ἀντύγων gripped to the chariot-rail, S. Aj. 1030, etc.; ἐκ τοῦ βραχίονος ἵππον ἐπέλκουσα leading it [by a rein] upon her arm, Hdt. 5.12 : with Verbs signifying hold, lead, ἐξ ἐκείνων ἔχειν τὰς ἐλπίδας to have their hopes dependent upon them, Th. 1.84 ; ἐκ χειρὸς ἄγειν lead by the hand, Bion Fr. 7.2 ; ἐκ ποδὸς ἕπεσθαι ib. 6.2 ; ἐκ τῆς οὐρᾶς λαμβάνεσθαι Luc. Asin. 23 : with the Art. indicating the place of origin, οἱ ἐκ τῶν νήσων κακοῦργοι the robbers of the islands, Th. 1.8, cf. 2.5, 13 ; τοὺς ἐκ τῆς ναυμαχίας those in the sea-fight, Pl. Ap. 32b ; τοὺς ἐκ τῶν σκηνῶν those in the tents, D. 18.169 ; ἁρπασόμενοι τὰ ἐκ τῶν οἰκιῶν X. Cyr. 7.2.5 ; οἱ ἐκ τοῦ πεδίου ἔθεον Id. An. 4.6.25 : even with Verbs of sitting or standing, εἰσεῖδε στᾶσʼ ἐξ Οὐλύμποιο from Olympus where she stood, Il. 14.154 ; καθῆσθαι ἐκ πάγων to sit on the heights and look from them, S. Ant. 411 ; στὰς ἐξ ἐπάλξεων ἄκρων E. Ph. 1009 ; ἐκ βυθοῦ at the bottom, Theoc. 22.40 : phrases, ἐκ δεξιᾶς, ἐξ ἀριστερᾶς, on the right, left, X. Cyr. 8.3.10, etc.; οἱ ἐξ ἐναντίας, οἱ ἐκ πλαγίοὐ ib. 7.1.20 ; ἐκ θαλάσσης, opp. ἐκ τῆς μεσογείας, D. 18.301.
νικᾶν ἔκ τινος win a victory over.., Apoc. 15.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἐξ οὗ [ χρόνου] since, Il. 1.6, Od. 2.27, etc.; in apod., ἐκ τοῦ from that time, Il. 8.296 ; ἐκ τούτου X. An. 5.8.15, etc. (but ἐκ τοῖο there after, Il. 1.493, and ἐκ τούτων or ἐκ τῶνδε usu. after this, X. Mem. 2.9.4, S. OT 235) ; ἐξ ἐκείνου Th. 2.15 ; ἐκ πολλοῦ (sc. χρόνου) for a long time, Id. 1.68, etc.; ἐκ πλέονος χρόνου Id. 8.45 ; ἐκ πλείστου ib. 68 ; ἐξ ὀλίγου at short notice, Id. 2.11 (but also a short time since, Plu. Caes. 28) ; ἐκ παλαιοῦ X. Mem. 3.5.8 ; ἐκ παλαιτάτου Th. 1.18.

ἐκ νεότητος..ἐς γῆρας Il. 14.86 ; ἐκ γενετῆς 24.535 ; ἐκ νέου, ἐκ παιδός, from boyhood, Pl. Grg. 510d, R. 374c, etc.; ἐκ μικροῦ παιδαρίου D. 53.19 ; ἐξ ἀρχῆς A. Eu. 284, etc.; καύματος ἔξ after hot weather, Il. 5.865; νέφος ἔρχεται οὐρανὸν εἴσω αἰθέρος ἐκ δίης after clear weather, 16.365 ; ἐκ δὲ αἰθρίης καὶ νηνεμίης συνδραμεῖν ἐξαπίνης νέφεα Hdt. 1.87 ; so (like ἀπό II) ἐκ τῆς θυσίης γενέσθαι to have just finished sacrifice, ib. 50, etc.; ἐκ τοῦ ἀρίστου after breakfast, X. An. 4.6.21 ; ἐξ εἰρήνης πολεμεῖν to go to war after peace, Th. 1.120 ; γελάσαι ἐκ τῶν ἔμπροσθεν δακρύων X. Cyr. 1.4.28 ; κάλλιστον ἦμαρ εἰσιδεῖν ἐκ χείματος A. Ag. 900 ; τὴν θάλασσαν ἐκ Διονυσίων πλόϊμον εἶναι Thphr. Char. 3.3 ; ἐκ χειμῶνος at the end of winter, Plu. Nic. 20.

data.quote: ἐκ δὲ αἰθρίης καὶ νηνεμίης συνδραμεῖν ἐξαπίνης νέφεα
τὴν θάλασσαν ἐκ Διονυσίων πλόϊμον εἶναι

children.definition: at, in, ἐκ νυκτῶν Od. 12.286 ; ἐκ νυκτός X. Cyr. 1.4.2, etc.; ἐξ ἡμέρας S. El. 780 ; ἐκ μέσω ἄματος Theoc. 10.5 ; ἐκ τοῦ λοιποῦ or ἐκ τῶν λοιπῶν for the future, X. Smp. 4.56, Pl. Lg. 709e.

out of or of which things are made, γίγνεταί τι ἔκ τινος Parm. 8.12 ; ποιέεσθαι ἐκ ξύλων τὰ πλοῖα Hdt. 1.194 ; πίνοντας ἐκ κριθῶν μέθυ A. Supp. 953 ; εἶναι ἐξ ἀδάμαντος Pl. R. 616c ; ἐκ λευκῶ ἐλέφαντος αἰετοί Theoc. 15.123 ; στράτευμα ἀλκιμώτατον ἂν γένοιτο ἐκ παιδικῶν X. Smp. 8.32 ; συνετάττετο ἐκ τῶν ἔτι προσιόντων formed line of battle from the troops as they marched up, Id. An. 1.8.14.

data.quote: στράτευμα ἀλκιμώτατον ἂν γένοιτο ἐκ παιδικῶν

children.definition: ἔκ τινος εἶναι, γενέσθαι, etc., Il. 20.106, 6.206, etc.; ἐκ γὰρ ἐμεῦ γένος ἐσσί (where γένος is acc. abs.) 5.896 ; σῆς ἐξ αἵματός εἰσι γενέθλης 19.111 ; ὦ παῖ πατρὸς ἐξ Ἀχιλλέως S. Ph. 260 ; πίρωμις ἐκ πιρώμιος Hdt. 2.143 ; ἀγαθοὶ καὶ ἐξ ἀγαθῶν Pl. Phdr. 246a ; τὸν ἐξ ἐμῆς μητρός S. Ant. 466, etc.

ἐκ Σιδῶνος..εὔχομαι εἶναι Od. 15.425, cf. Th. 1.25, etc.; ἐκ τῶν ἄνω εἰμί Ev.Jo. 8.23; ἡ ἐξ Ἀρείου πάγου βουλή the Areopagus, Arist. Ath. 4.4, etc. ; οἱ ἐκ τῆς διατριβῆς ταύτης Aeschin. 1.54 ; οἱ ἐκ τοῦ Περιπάτου the Peripatetics, Luc. Pisc. 43 ; ὁ ἐξ Ἀκαδημείας the Academic, Ath. 1.34b ; οἱ ἐκ πίστεως Ep.Gal. 3.7 ; οἱ ἐξ ἐριθείας Ep.Rom. 2.8.

ὄναρ, τιμὴ ἐκ Διός ἐστιν, Il. 1.63, 2.197, cf. Od. 1.33, A. Pers. 707, etc.; θάνατος ἐκ μνηστήρων death by the hand of the suitors, Od. 16.447 ; τὰ ἐξ Ἑλλήνων τείχεα walls built by them, Hdt. 2.148 ; κίνημα ἐξ αὑτοῦ spontaneous motion, Plot. 6.1.21 ; ὕμνος ἐξ Ἐρινύων A. Eu. 331 (lyr.) ; ἡ ἐξ ἐμοῦ δυσβουλία S. Ant. 95 ; ὁ ἐξ ἐμοῦ πόθος Id. Tr. 631.

Pass. Verbs, by, Poet. and early Prose, ἐφίληθεν ἐκ Διός they were beloved of ( i.e. by) Zeus, Il. 2.669 ; κήδεʼ ἐφῆπται ἐκ Διός ib. 70; προδεδόσθαι ἐκ Πρηξάσπεος Hdt. 3.62; τὰ λεχθέντα ἐξ Ἀλεξάνδρου Id. 7.175, cf. S. El. 124 (lyr.), Ant. 93, Th. 3.69, Pl. Ti. 47b; ἐξ ἁπάντων ἀμφισβητήσεται Id. Tht. 171b; ὁμολογουμένους ἐκ πάντων X. An. 2.6.1 ; τὰς ἐκ θεῶν τύχας δοθείσας S. Ph. 1316, cf. Pl. Ly. 204c : with neut. Verbs, ἐκ..πατρὸς κακὰ πείσομαι Od. 2.134, cf. A. Pr. 759 ; τλῆναί τι ἔκ τινος Il. 5.384 ; θνήσκειν ἔκ τινος S. El. 579, OT 854, etc.; τὰ γενόμενα ἐξ ἀνθρώπων Hdt. 1.1.

by which a thing is done, ἐκ πατέρων φιλότητος in consequence of our fathers’ friendship, Od. 15.197 ; μήνιος ἐξ ὀλοῆς 3.135 ; ἐξ ἔριδος Il. 7.111 ; τελευτῆσαι ἐκ τοῦ τρώματος Hdt. 3.29 ; ἐκ τίνος λόγου; E. Andr. 548 ; ἐκ τοῦ; wherefore? Id. Hel. 93 ; λέξον ἐκ τίνος ἐπλήγης X. An. 5.8.4 ; ποιεῖτε ὑμῖν φίλους ἐκ τοῦ Μαμωνᾶ τῆς ἀδικίας make yourselves friends of ( i.e. by means of).., Ev.Luc. 16.9 ; ζῆν ἔκ τινος X. HG 3.2.11 codd.; ἐκ τῶν ἰδίων τρέφειν ἐμαυτόν Isoc. 15.152 ; ἐκ τόξων ἀνύσαι γαστρὶ φορβάν S. Ph. 710 (lyr.).

in accordance with, ἐκ τῶν λογίων Hdt. 1.64 ; ὁ ἐκ τῶν νόμων χρόνος D. 24.28 ; ἐκ κελεύματος A. Pers. 397, cf. Sophr. 25 ; ἐκ τῶν ξυγκειμένων Th. 5.25 ; ἐκ τῶν παρόντων ib. 40, etc.; ἐκ τῶν ἔργων κρινόμενοι X. Cyr. 2.2.21, cf. A. Pr. 485.

Adv., ἐκ προνοίας IG 1(2).115.11 ; ἐκ βίας by force, S. Ph. 563 ; ἐκ δόλου Id. El. 279 ; ἐκ παντὸς τρόπου ζητεῖν Pl. R. 499a : esp. with neut. Adjs., ἐξ ἀγχιμόλοιο, = ἀγχίμολον, Il. 24.352 ; ἐκ τοῦ ἐμφανέος Hdt. 3.150; ἐκ τοῦ φανεροῦ, ἐκ τοῦ προφανοῦς, Th. 4.106, 6.73 ; ἐκ προδήλου S. El. 1429 ; ἐξ ἴσου, ἐκ τοῦ ἴσου, Id. Tr. 485, Th. 2.3 ; ἐξ ἀέλπτου Hdt. 1.111, etc.: with fem. Adj., ἐκ τῆς ἰθέης Id. 3.127 ; ἐκ νέης Id. 5.116 ; ἐξ ὑστέρης Id. 6.85 ; ἐκ τῆς ἀντίης Id. 8.6 ; ἐκ καινῆς Th. 3.92 ; ἐξ ἑκουσίας S. Tr. 727 ; ἐκ ταχείας ib. 395.
ἐκ τρίτων in the third place, E. Or. 1178, Pl. Grg. 500a, Smp. 213b ; distributively, apiece, Ath. 15.671b.

children.label: b
children.definition: ἐξ ὀκτὼ ὀβολῶν SIG 2587.206 ; ἐκ τριῶν δραχμῶν ib. 283 ; συμφωνήσας ἐκ δηναρίου Ev.Matt. 20.2.

children.label: c
children.definition: ἐπιπέμματα ἐξ ἡμιχοινικίου Inscr.Prien. 362 (iv B.C.).

children.label: d
children.definition: θινώδης ὢν ὁ τόπος ἐξ εἴκοσι σταδίων by the space of twenty stades, Str. 8.3.19.

children.label: B
children.definition: ἐκ is freq. separated from its CASE, Il. 11.109, etc.—It takes an accent in anastrophe, 14.472, Od. 17.518.— Ep. use it with Advbs. in -θεν, ἐξ οὐρανόθεν, ἐξ ἁλόθεν, ἐξ Αἰσύμηθεν, Il. 17.548, 21.335, 8.304 ; ἐκ Διόθεν Hes. Op. 765 ; ἐκ πρῴρηθεν Theoc. 22.11.—It is combined with other Preps. to make the sense more definite, as διέκ, παρέκ, ὑπέκ.

children.label: C
children.definition: removal prevails ; out, away, off.
completion, like our utterly, ἐκπέρθω, ἐξαλαπάζω, ἐκβαρβαρόω, ἐκδιδάσκω, ἐκδιψάω, ἐκδωριεύομαι, ἐξοπλίζω, ἐξομματόω, ἔκλευκος, ἔκπικρος.

children.label: D
children.definition: therefrom, Il. 18.480.

definition: Ἑκαδήμεια, ἡ, old form for Ἀκαδήμεια, from the name of a hero Hecademos, D.L. 3.8.

Ἑκάεργος, ὁ, expld. by Gramm. ( EM 319.51, etc.) as, = ὁ ἕκαθεν εἴργων or ἐργαζόμενος, Ep. epith. of Apollo, either Subst., Il. 1.147, etc., or Adj., 5.439, Od. 8.323, Call. Ap. 11, etc. : fem., ὦ ἑκάεργε, of Artemis, Ar. Th. 972 (lyr.) :—also Ἑκαέργη, a daughter of Boreas, Call. Del. 292.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pythag. name for nine, ἀπὸ τοῦ εἴργειν τὴν ἑκὰς πρόβασιν τοῦ ἀριθμοῦ Theol.Ar. 58. (This word and its cognates (e.g. ἑκατηβελέτης), although connected by Greek writers with ἑκάς, may have originally contained the stem ἑκṇ τ-(cf. ἑκών) ‘at willʼ; for the formation of ϝεκα (τ) -ϝεργός, cf. γυναι (κ) -μανής.)

data.quote: ἀπὸ τοῦ εἴργειν τὴν ἑκὰς πρόβασιν τοῦ ἀριθμοῦ

children.definition: from afar, Il. 2.456, Pi. O. 10(11).7, A. Supp. 421 (lyr.), and late Prose, Corn. ND 32, D.C. 50.33 : c. gen., ἕκαθεν πόλιος Il. 13.107 (al. ἑκάς).

children.label: II
children.definition: far off, far away, Od. 17.25.

children.label: III
children.definition: Schwyzer 702 ( Erythrae, iv B.C.).

definition: Ἑκάλειος Ζεύς [ᾰ], from Ἑκάλη, a lady who entertained Theseus, and for this received at Athens the yearly honour of the Ἑκαλήσια [ ἱερά]: hence the epith. was given to Zeus as worshipped on the same day, Plu. Thes. 14.
ἑκαλία πόρρωθεν, Hsch. ἐκάλλιθμος· ἱερός, ἀφειμένος, Id.
ἕκαλος, Dor. for ἕκηλος, Pi. O. 9.58, I. 7(6).41.

children.definition: afar, far off, Il. 20.422, etc.; οὐχ ἑκάς που S. Ph. 41 ; rare in Prose, Th. 1.69, 80 (and later, Nic.Dam. p.6D.) : c. gen., far from, far away from, ἑ. Ἄργεος Il. 9.246, etc.: freq. following its case, 13.263, Od. 14.496, al.; οὐ Χαρίτων ἑ. Pi. P. 8.21, cf. E. Ph. 907 ; ἑ. ἀπὸ τείχεος Il. 18.256 ; ἀπὸ τῆς νήσου ἑ. Hdt. 3.41.

Comp. ἑκαστέρω farther, Od. 7.321, h.Bacch. 29, Alc. Supp. 5.8 ( ἐκ-), Hdt. 6.108, E. HF 1047 (lyr.), etc.: c. gen., Hdt. 2.169, al. ; also ἑκαστοτέρω dub. in Theoc. 15.7 : Sup. ἑκαστάτω farthest, Il. 10.113, Hdt. 4.33 : c. gen., τοὺς ἑωυτῶν ἑ. οἰκημένους farthest from.., Id. 1.134 ; τῆς Λιβύης ἑ. ἦλθε to the farthest point of Libya, Id. 4.204, cf. 9.14.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑ. ἐών afar, i.e. long after, Pi. P. 2.54 ; οὐχ ἑ. χρόνου in no long time, Hdt. 8.144 ; οὐχ ἑ. A. Ag. 1650. [ ᾰ ; ᾱ only in Call. Ap. 2, in arsi.] (Prob. from ἕ and -κάς as in ἀνδρακάς ; lit. ‘by himself’.)

definition: ἐκάς, άδος, ἡ, a division of land (?), Rev.Phil. 48.98 ( Dura).

children.definition: each or every time, IG 9(I).694.8 (Corc.) ; οἱ ἑκαστάκις ἐόντες ἄρχοντες, = οἱ ἀεὶ ἄ., ib. 22 :
everywhere, Suid.; f.l. for ἕκαστα in X. Cyr. 6.2.5.
from every side, Th. 7.20, 21, X. HG 3.4.3.
on each side, Plu. Lys. 19, PLips. 119r.
to each side, every way, Plu. Mar. 20, Hdn.Gr. 1.502.
to each side, Th. 4.55, 8.5, Pl. Criti. 116a.
everywhere, Th. 3.82, Pl. Phdr. 257e, al.
Cleobul. ap. D.L. 1.93.
for each or every one, Od. 3.8 (v.l. ἑκάστοθεν), Aen.Tact. 11.11.

each, opp. the whole body, Il. 2.805, etc. : sg. with pl. Verb, ἔβαν οἶκόνδε ἕκαστος they went home each to his own house, 1.606 ; δεδμήμεσθα ἕκαστος 5.878, cf. Hdt. 3.158 ; so in Att., Ar. Pl. 785, Pl. Prt. 327e, etc. ; ὅτι ἕκαστος ἐπίστασθε ἀγαθόν X. Smp. 3.3 : sg. in apposition with pl. Noun or Pron., which expresses the whole, Τρῶας δὲ τρόμος αἰνὸς ὑπήλυθε γυῖα ἕκαστον Il. 7.215 ; ὔμμι..ἑκάστῳ 15.109 ; αἱ δὲ γυναῖκες..θαύμαζον..ἑκάστη 18.496, etc. ; Περσίδες δʼ.. ἑκάστα..λείπεται A. Pers. 135 (lyr.) ; αἱ ἄλλαι πᾶσαι [ τέχναι] τὸ αὑτῆς ἑκάστη ἔργον ἐργάζεται Pl. R. 346d, cf. Grg. 503e ; ὅστις ἕκαστος every one which.. (nisi leg. ὥς τις), Hes. Th. 459.

data.quote: Τρῶας δὲ τρόμος αἰνὸς ὑπήλυθε γυῖα ἕκαστον

children.definition: Subst. (so regularly in earlier Att. Inscrr., IG 1(2).22.14, al., exc. ἑκάστου μηνός ib. 6.125) with which ἕκαστος agrees, in which case ἕκαστος is commonly put first, καθʼ ἑ. τὴν ἡμέραν every single day, Isoc. 12.211, etc. ; περὶ ἑ. τῆς τέχνης Pl. Phdr. 274e : also following the Subst., κατὰ τὸν ὁπλίτην ἕκαστον Th. 5.49 ; κατὰ τὴν ἡμέραν ἑκάστην Id. 6.63, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: all and each severally, Il. 1.550, al., A. Supp. 932, etc. ; οἷστισιν ἑκάστοις to whichsoever severally, Pl. Lg. 799a.
each of two or more groups or parties, Od. 9.164, Hdt. 1.169, A. Pr. 491, Th. 6.77, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: εἷς ἕ. (v. εἷς) ; εἷς τις ἕ. S. Ant. 262 ; ἕκαστός τις each one, Pi. N. 4.92, Th. 3.45, etc. ; ταῦτα ἕκαστα Hdt. 5.13, etc. ; αὔθʼ ἕκαστα all in exact detail, A. Pr. 950.

κατά, καθʼ ἕκαστον singly, by itself, Pl. Tht. 188a, al. ; καθʼ ἕ. καὶ σύμπαντα Id. Sph. 259b ; τὸ καθʼ ἕ., τὰ καθʼ ἕκαστα, particulars, Arist. Ph. 189a6, EN 1143b4, al. ; παρʼ ἕκαστον, παρʼ ἕκαστα, in every case, Plb. 4.82.5, 3.57.4, etc. ; παρʼ ἕκαστον καὶ ἔργον καὶ λόγον διδάσκοντες Pl. Prt. 325d ; παρʼ ἕκαστον λέγων constantly interjecting, Men. Epit. 48.

data.quote: παρʼ ἕκαστον καὶ ἔργον καὶ λόγον διδάσκοντες

children.definition: ὡς ἕκαστοι each by himself, Hdt. 6.79, Th. 1.15, etc. : in sg., τῶν δὲ ὡς ἑκάστῳ θύειν θέλει Hdt. 1.132, cf. Pi. P. 9.98 ; οὐχ ὡς ἕ. ἀλλὰ πάντες Arist. Pol. 1292a12, cf. 1283b34.

data.quote: τῶν δὲ ὡς ἑκάστῳ θύειν θέλει

children.label: IV
children.definition: D.H. 3.2 codd. ( ϝέκαστος Leg.Gort. 1.9, al., Schwyzer 409.4 ( Elis), IG 9(1).334.9 ( Locris). Apptly. connected with ἑκάς by Dam. Pr. 423.)
each time, on each occasion, Parm. 16.1, Hdt. 1.90, Antipho 6.13, X. An. 2.4.10, Pl. R. 393b ; ἀεὶ..ἑ. Ar. Nu. 1280 ; ἑ. πολλάκις Pl. Phlb. 58a ; ἵνα ἑ. wherever on each occasion, Hdt. 8.115.

definition: ἑκαταβόλος, ον, Dor. for ἑκατηβ-, Terp. 2, Tim. Pers. 249.

children.definition: of Hecate, μαγίδες S. Fr. 734.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑκάταιον or Ἑκάτειον (cj. in Ar. V. 804, cf. Suid.), τό, statue or chapel of Hecate, placed at the entrance of houses or where three roads meet ( ἐν τριόδοις), Ar. l.c., Ra. 366, cf. Hsch.
Ἑκαταῖα, τά, v. Ἑκάτη II.
at each time, X. Cyr. 4.6.4 ; in both directions, Gal. UP 8.7.
kick the rump with one heel after another, Hsch. (but cf. ἑκατερίς). -η, Cret. Adv. on either side, Schwyzer 197.4 (iii B.C.) ; ϝεκ- ib. 186.18 (ii B.C.).

definition: ἑκάτερθε, before a vowel ἑκᾰτερ-θεν, poet. Adv.

children.definition: on each side, on either hand, ἀμφίπολός οἱ..ἑ. παρέστη Od. 1.335 ; τρεῖς ἑ. Il. 11.27, cf. A.R. 1.564 : also in late Ion. Prose, Aret. SD 2.3.
ἑ. οξμίλου Il. 3.340, 23.813, cf. 329 ; ἑ. πόληος Od. 6.263.

definition: ἑκατερίς, ίδος, ἡ, a dance with χειρῶν κίνησις, Poll. 4.102 (but cf. ἑκατερέω).
ἑκάτερος ( Dor. ϝεκ- Leg.Gort. 1.18, Michel 995 A 49 (Delph.)), α, ον,

children.definition: each of two, each singly, opp. ἀμφότεροι, Lys. 2.33 ; εἷς ἑ. Syngr. ap. D. 35.12 ; αὐτὸ τὸ ἑ. καὶ τὸ ἀμφότερον Pl. Hp.Ma. 303a, cf. Pi. I. 8(7).31, Th. 1.20, etc. ; when joined with a Subst., the Subst. almost always takes the Art. (so in Att. Inscrr. exc. IG 1(2).372.137), as ἐφʼ ἑ. τῷ κέρᾳ Th. 5.67 ; ἐπὶ τῷ κέρᾳ ἑ. Id. 4.93 ; ἑ. τῇ πόλει Id. 5.16 : sts. with Noun or Pron. in gen., ἑκάτερος ἡμῶν Id. 6.17 ; ἑκατέρᾳ τῶν χειρῶν D.S. 4.10 : as nom. to pl. Verb, sts. in pl., esp. when one or both parties are in pl., ἐδικαίευν ἑκάτεροι Hdt. 9.26, Pl. R. 348b, etc. : in sg. with Verb in pl., ταῦτα εἰπόντες ἀπῆλθον ἑκάτερος ἐπὶ τὰ προσήκοντα X. Cyr. 5.2.22, cf. 6.1.19 ; repeated in ref. to each of two parties, ἐὰν ἑκάτεροι ἑκατέρων τέμνωσιν ἀγρούς Pl. R. 470d : with Particles and Preps., ὡς ἑκάτεροι Th. 3.74 ; ἐφʼ ἑκάτερα both ways, Id. 5.73 ; καθʼ ἑκάτερα X. An. 5.6.7 ; ἐξ ἑκατέρων Luc. Am. 14.

data.quote: αὐτὸ τὸ ἑ. καὶ τὸ ἀμφότερον
ταῦτα εἰπόντες ἀπῆλθον ἑκάτερος ἐπὶ τὰ προσήκοντα

children.definition: Id. Alex. 49.
on either side, τᾶς τραπέζας Schwyzer 251 A 10 ( Cos).
on each side, on either hand, Hdt. 3.102, Th. 2.75 : c. gen., ἑ. τῆς πόλεως Id. 3.6 ; τὸ ἑ. μέρος Pl. Phd. 112e ; at each end, Gp. 5.27.4.
on both sides, by father and mother, Poll. 8.85.
on either side, Pi. O. 2.69, Hdt. 2.19, 106, Arist. Ath. 54.8, etc.
in either way, Pl. Lg. 895e, Ph. 1.316 ; in both languages, i.e. Greek and Latin, Inscr.Prien. 105.30 (i B.C.).
to either side, either way, ἀποβλέπειν, φοιτᾶν, X. An. 1.8.14, Pl. Grg. 523c.
both ways, καθιέναι Id. Phd. 112e ; τὰ ὑπερβάλλοντα ἑ. Id. R. 619a.
Hecate, lit. she who works her will, Hes. Th. 411, h.Cer. 25, 52, E. Fr. 955, etc. ; Ἑ. φωσφόρος Ar. Fr. 594a, E. Fr. 968.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑκάτης δεῖπνον Hecateʼs dinner, a meal set out by rich persons at the foot of her statue ἐν τριόδοις on the 30th day of each month, when it became a sort of dole for beggars and paupers, Ar. Pl. 594 et Sch. ad loc., cf. Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.280c, 290d, AB 247 : hence, as it consisted of offal, Ἑκαταῖα κατεσθίειν, of a rapscallion, D. 54.39, cf. Luc. DMort. 1.1.
stake to which criminals were bound for scourging, Hsch.
= sq., ἄναξ Il. 1.75, Hes. Sc. 100 : Subst., h.Ap. 157 :—fem. ἑκᾰτη-βελέτις, ιδος, ἡ, Pythag. name for six, Theol.Ar. 37.

Hom., Hes.: as Subst., Il. 15.231 ; also of Artemis, h.Hom. 9.6. (Expld. by the ancients as, = far-darting, Hsch., etc. (or, shooting a hundred βέλη, Id.) ; but perh. originally, hitting the mark at will, cf. ἑκάεργος.)
Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.193f.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἑκατήσια, τά, festival of Hecate, SIG 1066.15 ( Cos).

children.label: III
children.definition: Adj., Ἑκατήσιος, α, ον, of Hecate, Man. 5.302, Poll. 1.37.

definition: ἕκατι, Dor. and Trag. for ἕκητι (q.v.), Pi. O. 4.10, E. Or. 26, etc.

children.definition: of Hecate, φάσματα Marin. Procl. 28 ; λόγοι Tab.Defix.Aud. 41 A II (written -ικίοις).
with a hundred limbs or bodies, κορᾶν ἀγέλα ἑκατόγγυιος a band of 100 maidens, Pi. Fr. 122.15.
hundred-headed, Pi. O. 4.8, Ar. Ra. 473, Nu. 336.

definition: ἑκατόγχειρ, χειρος, ὁ, ἡ, = sq., Acus. 8 J., Pi. Pae. 8.31, Orph. Fr. 57, al., Corn. ND 17, etc.

children.definition: hundred-handed, of Briareus, Il. 1.402.
with 100 benches for rowers, Il. 20.247.

definition: Ἑκατόμβαιος, α, ον, epith. of Apollo and Zeus,

children.definition: to whom hecatombs were offered, Hsch., EM 321.7.
μήν) name of a month, Hemerolog.Flor.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑκατόμβαια, τά, = ἑκατόμβοια, CIG 1715 (Delph.).
the month Hecatombaeon, in which ἑκατόμβαι were offered at Athens and elsewhere, Antipho 6.44, Plu. Thes. 12, IG ΙΙ(2).203 A 31, al.( Delos, iii B.C.), etc.; μῆνα ἐμβάλλειν Ἑ. ib. 12.76.53.

definition: Ἑκατομβεύς, έως, ὁ(sc. μήν), = foreg., at Sparta. Hsch.

children.definition: an offering of a hundred oxen; but even in Hom., generally, sacrifice, Il. 6.115 (apptly. of twelve oxen, cf. 93), Od. 3.59 ; of bulls and goats, Il. 1.315 ; of fifty rams, 23.146 ; of three victims, Schwyzer 726.19 ( Milet.) ; Com., πουλυπόδων ἑ. Anaxandr. 41.29 (anap.) ; ᾠῶν ἑ. Ephipp. 8.4 : metaph., ὅστις στρατηγεῖ μὴ στρατιώτης γενόμενος οὗτος ἑ. ἐξάγει τοῖς πολεμίοις Men. 640.

data.quote: ὅστις στρατηγεῖ μὴ στρατιώτης γενόμενος οὗτος ἑ. ἐξάγει τοῖς πολεμίοις

children.label: II
children.definition: eye-salve, Alex.Trall. 2.

children.label: II
children.definition: μήν) name of month at Halos, IG 9(2).109b50.

children.label: III
children.definition: Ἑκατόμβιον, τό, shrine of Apollo Ἑκατόμβιος, ib. 9(1).87.76 ( Hyampolis).
Ἑκατόμβια, τά, = Ἑκατόμβοια, at Amorgos, IG 12(7).388, al.
worth a hundred oxen, Il. 2.449, etc.: expld. as worth 100 pieces of money, the ancient coins being stamped with an ox, Eust. 252.18, EM 320.47.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑκατόμβοια (sc. ἱερά), τά, festival at which hecatombs were offered, SIG 36.36 (Delph., V B.C.), 82.6 (Delph., V B.C.), BCH 29.243 ( Delos), IG 5(2).142 ( Tegea), Str. 8.4.11 codd.: dat. Ἑκατομβούοις (sic) Schwyzer 91.19 ( Argos).

a hundred feet long, πυρὴ ἑκατόμπεδος ἔνθα καὶ ἔνθα a hundred feet all ways, Il. 23.164 ; νεώς Th. 3.68 (v.l. -ποδος), IG 1(2).256, al., cf. Pi. I. 6(5).22, Tab.Heracl. 2.24, al.; ὁ ἑ. Παρθενών Plu. Per. 13 ; ἡ ἑ. Id. Dio 45 ; τὸ Ἑ. on the Acropolis of Athens, IG 1(2).4.10, 18 ; at Dodona, Ptol. Geog. 3.13.5.
of 100 cubits, Hsch. and Apollon. Lex. s.v. ἑκατόγχειρον.
with a hundred cities, Κρήτη Il. 2.649 ; of Laconia, Str. 8.4.11 :—also ἑκᾰτοντάπολις [τᾰ], Κρήτη Id. 10.4.15.

hundred-footed: in S. OC 718 (lyr.), ἑκατόμποδες Νηρηΐδες, some take it literally to mean the 50 Nereids (the number assigned to them by Hes. Th. 264, Pi. I. 6(5).6, A. Fr. 174, E. IT 427), others the 100 Nereids ( Pl. Criti. 116e), others merely to express a notion of multitude.
hundred-gated, Θῆβαι Il. 9.383, D.P. 249.
sacrifice for a hundred enemies slain, Paus. 4.19.3, Plu. Symp. 2.159e, Rom. 25, Polyaen. 2.31.2.

definition: ἑκατόν, Arc. ἑκοτόν IG 5(2).3 ( Tegea, iv B.C.), οἱ, αἱ, τά, indecl.:—

children.definition: a hundred, Il. 2.510, etc.: in compds. freq. loosely for very many. (Dissim. from sém kṃtóm, cf. εἷς and Lat. centum, Lith. šiṁtas, etc.)
holder of 110 ἄρουραι, PCair.Zen. 1.23 (iii B.C.).
Hsch.
sum of 100 staters, Leg.Gort. 9.47.
in a hundred books, πραγματεῖαι Gal. 10.37.
having a hundred letters, ὄνομα PMag.Par. 1.1209, 1380.
holding a hundred, ἀνδρῶνες Jul. Ep. 180.
weighing a hundred drachms, Gal. 13.491.
170 times as great, Olymp. in Mete. 118.21 : - also ἑκατοντᾰκαιεβδ-, Ptol. Alm. 5.16.
period of 100 years, Pl. R. 615a.
of a hundred years, Orph. A. 1108.
of a hundred years, βιοτά Pi. P. 4.282 ; 100 years old, LXX Ge. 17.17.
period of 100 years, Ph. 1.101.
with a hundred tassels, αἰγίς Jul. Ep. 180.
hundred-headed, Pi. P. 1.16.
= foreg., γίγας Jul. Ep. 180.
times, Ptol. Alm. 5.19.
hundred times, Hero Bel. 113.7, Orib. Fr. 113.
with 100 couches, with room for 100 couches, of a room, Chares ap. Ath. 12.538c, D.S. 17.16, J. BJ 5.4.4.
with a hundred steps, βωμοί Jul. Ep. 180.
sum of 100 talents, Poll. 9.52.
worth 100 talents, γραφὴ ἑ. an action for damages laid at that sum, Ar. Eq. 442.
able to fight 100 men, J. AJ 13.12.5.
a compound remedy, Gal. 14.152.
consisting of 100 men, λοχαγία Jul. Ep. 180.
Jul. Ep. 180.
of 100 cubits, J. BJ 2.10.2.
= sq., Simp. in Ph. 1115.33. Adv. -ίως LXX 1 Ch. 21.3.
a hundred times as much or many, c. gen., X. Oec. 2.3 : without gen., a hundredfold, LXX 2 Ki. 24.8; καρπός Ev.Luc. 8.8.
of 100 plethra, ἄρουραι Jul. Ep. 180.
AP 7.7, cf. Jul. Ep. 180 ; Ῥώμη IG 14.1389ii3 ( -οπυλ - lapis).
holder of 100 ἄρουραι, PHal. 20.4, 5 (iii B.C.), PGiss. 2.10 (ii B.C.), etc.
to be a centurion, D.C. 52.25.
leader of a hundred, Hdt. 7.81, A. Fr. 182 ; = ταξίαρχος (q.v.), Ascl. Tact. 2.8, etc. ; = Lat. centurio, D.H. 2.13 (v.l. -χοι), Act.Ap. 10.1, J. AJ 9.7.2, Plu. Pomp. 78, etc.
post of a centurion, Onos. 34.2 (pl.), D.C. 78.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: centurionʼs command, century, J. BJ 3.6.2, Ph. 2.33 (pl.).
body of 128 light-armed troops, Ascl. Tact. 6.3, etc.
eye-salve, Aët. 7.11, al.
X. Cyr. 5.3.41, Ev.Matt. 8.5, Ph. 2.131, Plu. Luc. 35, Arr. Tact. 10.3.
a hundred, Hdt. 7.184 : pl., Ph. 2.423, Jul. Ep. 180.
having 100 columns, Aristeas 116, BCH 11.100 ( Thyatira).
with 100 petals, ῥόδα Thphr. HP 6.6.4.
Plu. Frat. 2.478f (as v.l.), Jul. Ep. 180: also ἑκᾰτοντά-χειρος, ον, Hsch. s.v. Βριάρεῳ.
of 100 measures : yielding fruit a hundredfold, Thphr. HP 8.7.4 ; κριθή Str. 15.3.11.
sacrifice of 100 kids, IG 12(5).908 ( Tenos).
fathoms high, ἀνδριάς Pi. Fr. 282 : in Ar. Av. 1131 μῆκος ἑκατοντορόγυιον shd. be read.
hundred-oared, Poll. 1.82.

definition: ἑκατοντούτης, ου, ὁ, contr. for ἑκατονταέτης, Luc. Macr. 14 :—fem. ἑκᾰτοντ-οῦτις, ιδος, Ath. 15.697e.

ἕκατος, ὁ, shortd. fr. ἑκατη-βόλος (q.v.), epith. of Apollo, Il. 7.83, 20.295 :—as Subst., ἕκατος, ὁ, 1.385, 20.71 (connected with ἑκατόν (sc. βέλη) by Simon. 26 A) :—fem. ἑκάτη, epith. of Artemis, A. Supp. 676 (lyr.), Corn. ND 32.

children.definition: bear a hundredfold, LXX Ge. 26.12.
subject to a tax of one per cent., οἰκίη GDI 5661.13 ( Chios) :— Subst. ἑκᾰτοστ-ηρία, Ion. -ιη, ἡ, tax of one per cent., ib. 48, PCair.Zen. 12.76, al.
of 1/100 monthly, i.e. twelve per cent. per ann., IG 2(2).1104.4, PGrenf. 2.89 (vi A.D.).
a 128th part, Nicom. Ar. 1.8.
120th, Paul.Aeg. 2.6.
hundred-mouthed, E. Ba. 406 (lyr.).
hundredth, Hdt. 1.47, etc. ; ἐπʼ ἑκατοστὰ ἐκφέρειν to bear a hundredfold, Id. 4.198.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑκατοστή, ἡ, tax of one per cent., Ar. V. 658, X. Ath. 1.17, PGnom. 85, etc. ; ἐκ τῶν χρημάτων ἑ. IG 2.721 Ai 12 : also, = τόκοι ἑκατοστιαῖοι, Plu. Luc. 20.
having 100 columns (sc. κρήνη), Abh.Berl.Akad. 1904(2).13.
X. Cyr. 6.3.34, Plu. Rom. 8.

children.label: II
children.definition: a hundred, Aen.Tact. 11.10a, IPE 12.79.30 ( Olbia, i A.D.), Milet. 3 No.153 ( Byzantium), SIG 645.61 (Seleucia Cilic., ii B.C.), CIG 3641b ( Lampsacus), etc.
hundred-petalled rose, Gloss.

definition: ἑκατῶρυξ, ῠγος, ὁ, dub. sens. in IPE 4.80 B6.
ἐκβαβάζω (or perh. ἐκβαβράζω), glossed by ἐκσαλεύω, S. Fr. 139 (ap. Hsch.).

children.definition: speak out, declare, A. Ag. 498.

definition: ἐκβαίνω, fut. -βήσομαι : aor. ἐξέβην : pf. ἐκβέβηκα :—

children.definition: step out of or off from, c. gen., πέτρης ἐκβαίνοντα Il. 4.107 ; ἔκβαινʼ ἀπήνης A. Ag. 906 ; ἐ. ἐκ τῆς νεώς Th. 1.137 (so in tmesi, ἐκ δὲ Χρυσηΐς νηὸς βῆ Il. 1.439) : abs., step out of a ship or chariot, disembark, dismount, ἐκ δʼ ἔβαν αὐτοί 3.113, cf. 1.437, Hdt. 4.196, etc. ; step out of the sea, Od. 5.415, 7.278 ; debouch from a defile, X. An. 4.2.3 ; καταστρατοπεδεύσασθαι ἐπὶ λόφον ἐκβάντες ib. 6.3.20 : rarely exc. of persons, but βοὴ ..ἐξέβη νάπους S. Aj. 892.

go out of, depart from, ψυχὴ ἐ. ἐκ τοῦ σώματος Pl. Phd. 77d ; ἐκ τοῦ πολέμου Plb. 3.40.7 : c. gen., ἐ. τύχης E. IT 907 ; ἐ. τῆς ἑαυτοῦ ἰδέας Pl. R. 380d ; τῆς λεκτικῆς ἁρμονίας Arist. Po. 1449a27 ; τι τῆς εἰωθυίας διαίτης Pl. R. 406b ; ἔνθεν ἐ. Id. Ti. 44e ; withdraw from, ἐκ τῆς νομοθεσίας Id. Lg. 744a ; μισθώσεως, γεωργίας, BGU 1120.52 (i B.C.), PTeb. 309.14 (ii A.D.).
leave, τὴν πλατεῖαν Herod. 6.53, cf. Phld. D. 3.11 : but,

children.label: b
children.definition: outstep, overstep, γαίας ὅρια E. HF 82 ; τὴν ἡλικίαν τοῦ γεννᾶν Pl. R. 461b ; τριάκοντα ἔτη ib. 537d ; τὸν ὅρκον v.l. in Id. Smp. 183b ; τὸ μέσον Arist. Pol. 1296a26.
ἐκβὰς .. ἁρμάτων πόδα E. Heracl. 802.
to be produced, of crops, οἱ ἐκβησόμενοι καρποί PLips. 23.20 (iv A.D.), etc.
project, of ground, PTeb. 84.91 (ii B.C.).
come out, turn out, Hdt. 7.209 ; τῇ περ ὥρων ἐκβησόμενα πρήγματα ταῦτα ibid. ; τὰ μέλλοντά σφι ἐκβαίνειν ib. 221, cf. Th. 7.14, etc. ; of a total obtained by measurement, PAmh. 2.31 (ii B.C.).

to be fulfilled, of prophecies, etc., D. 19.28 ; also τοιοῦτον ἐκβέβηκεν S. Tr. 672 ; κάκιστος ἐ. to prove a villain, E. Med. 229 ; κατὰ νοῦν ἐ. τινί Pl. Mx. 247d ; ἄν τι μὴ κατὰ γνώμην ἐκβῇ D. 1.16 ; τὸ ἐκβάν, τὰ ἐκβαίνοντα, the issue, event, D. 1.11, Plb. 2.27.5.

data.quote: ἄν τι μὴ κατὰ γνώμην ἐκβῇ

children.definition: go out of due bounds, ἐς τοῦτʼ ἐκβέβηκʼ ἀλγηδόνος E. Med. 56 ; ποῖποτʼ ἐξέβης λόγῳ ; S. Ph. 896 ; ἐξέβην γὰρ ἄλλοσε I wandered elsewhere in thought, E. IT 781 ; in writing, digress, ἐπάνειμι ἔνθεν ἐξέβην X. HG 6.5.1, cf. 7.4.1, D. 18.211, Pl. Lg. 864c.
project, extend beyond a limit, POxy. 918 xi 20 (ii A.D.) : metaph., transcend, ἐ. ὑπὲρ τὸ μέγα ὂν καὶ ὑπὲρ τὸ μικρόν Porph. Sent. 34.

data.quote: ἐ. ὑπὲρ τὸ μέγα ὂν καὶ ὑπὲρ τὸ μικρόν

children.definition: lapse, πρὶν ἐκβῆναί τινι τὴν στρατηγίαν App. Syr. 23.
ἐκβαίνοντος μηνός, = φθίνοντος μ., IG 14.105 (Syracus.).

children.label: B
children.definition: aor. 1 -έβησα :— cause to go out, esp. put ashore, land from a ship, ἐκ δʼ ἑκατόμβην βῆσαν Il. 1.438 ; οἱ δʼ ἐκβήσαντές [σε] ἔβησαν (where ἔβησαν is aor. 2) Od. 24.301 ; ἐς γαῖαν ἐξέβησέ [με] E. Hel. 1616.
Bacchic enthusiasm, Eun. VS p.470 B.

excite to Bacchic frenzy, φρένας E. Tr. 408, cf. Pl. Phdr. 245a ; τὰς σοφιστικὰς ὑποθέσεις Philostr. VS 2.10.4 ; cause to rage with anger, Phld. Ir. p.63 W.:— Pass., to be filled with Bacchic frenzy, πᾶσα δʼ ἐξεβακχεύθη πόλις E. Ba. 1295, cf. Pl. R. 561a, Hdn. 5.8.1, etc. ; ἔρωτι Aristaenet. 1.16 ; ὑπὸ τοῦ ἔρωτος Max.Tyr. 24.9 [18.9.i] :— Med., E. Supp. 1001 (lyr.) :— intr. in Act., Alex. 141.13 ; of anger, Phld. Ir. p.35 W.

definition: ἐκβάλλω, Arc. ἐσδέλλω IG 5(2).6.49 ( Tegea, iv B.C.), fut. -βᾰλῶ: aor. -έβαλον : pf. -βέβληκα : Pass., fut. -βεβλήσομαι E. Ba. 1313 :—

children.definition: throw or cast out of, c. gen., Ὀδίον μέγαν ἔκβαλε δίφρου Il. 5.39, etc. : abs., throw out, ἐκ δʼ εὐνὰς ἔβαλον 1.436, etc. ; καὶ τὴν μὲν..ἰχθύσι κύρμα γενέσθαι ἔκβαλον threw her overboard, Od. 15.481, cf. Hdt. 1.24 : then in various relations, ἐκπίπτω being freq. used as its Pass. :

throw ashore, τὸν δʼ ἄρʼ..νεὸς ἔκβαλε κῦμʼ ἐπὶ χέρσου Od. 19.278 ; ἄνεμος.. τρηχέως περιέσπε..πολλὰς τῶν νεῶν ἐκβάλλων πρὸς τὸν Ἄθων Hdt. 6.44 ; ἐ. ἐς τὴν γῆν Id. 7.170 (but in 2.113 ἄνεμοι..ἐκβάλλουσι ἐς τὸ πέλαγος carry out to sea ; ἐξέβαλεν ἄνεμος ἡμᾶς drove us out of our course, E. Cyc. 20) :— Med., put ashore, ἵππους ἐξεβάλλοντο Hdt. 6.101 ; jettison, Syngr. ap. D. 35.11.

data.quote: τὸν δʼ ἄρʼ..νεὸς ἔκβαλε κῦμʼ ἐπὶ χέρσου
ἄνεμος.. τρηχέως περιέσπε..πολλὰς τῶν νεῶν ἐκβάλλων πρὸς τὸν Ἄθων

children.definition: cast out of a place, Κιμμερίους ἐκβαλόντες ἐκ τῆς Εὐρώπης Hdt. 1.103 ; ἐ. ἐκ τῆς χώρας, of an enemy, Lycurg. 99, cf. D. 60.8 ; esp. of banishment, ἐκ πόλεως ἐ. drive out of the country, Pl. Grg. 468d, cf. Ar. Pl. 430, etc. ; of a corpse, ἔξω τῆς πόλεως, τῶν ὁρίων, Pl. Lg. 873b, 909c : c. acc. only. drive out, banish, Heraclit. 121, S. OC 646, 770, etc. ; turn out, νεοττούς Arist. HA 618b12 ; cast out of the synagogue, Ev.Jo. 34 ; ἐκ τοῦ τάγματος J. BJ 2.8.8 ; exorcize, cast out evil spirits, Ev.Marc. 1.34, al. ; also in weakened sense, cause to depart, ib. 43.
expose on a desertisland, S. Ph. 257, 1034, 1390 ; expose a dead body, ταφῆς ἄτερ Id. Aj. 1388 ; ἐ. τέκνα expose children, E. Ion 964.
ἐ. γυναῖκα ἐκ τῆς οἰκίας divorce her, D. 59.83 : with simple acc., And. 1.125, D. 59.63, D.S. 12.18, etc. :— Pass., LXX Le. 21.7.

cast out of his seat, depose a king, ἐ. ἕδρας Κρόνον A. Pr. 203 ; ἐκ τυραννίδος θρόνου τʼ ib. 910 ; ἐκ τῆς τιμῆς X. Cyr. 1.3.9 : without ἐκ, ἐ. τινὰ πλούτου S. El. 649 :— Pass., to be ejected, of an occupier, PPetr. 2p.143 (iii B.C.), PMagd. 12.8 (iii B.C.), etc. ; χάριτος ἐκβεβλημένη S. Aj. 808 ; ἐκ τῆς φιλίας X. An. 7.5.6 ; ἐκ τῆς ἀρχῆς ἐξεβλήθησαν Isoc. 4.70.
throw decisively in wrestling. τίνʼ οὐ παλαίουσʼ ἐς τρὶς ἐ. ; S. Fr. 941.13.

data.quote: τίνʼ οὐ παλαίουσʼ ἐς τρὶς ἐ. ;

children.definition: ἐ. φρέατα dig wells, Plu. Pomp. 32.
get rid of, τοξεύματα Dsc. 3.32.
expel afterbirth, Hp. Mul. 1.78.
publish, σύνταξιν Plb. 30.4.11 ; issue, δόγμα ib. 19.6 ; ἀπόκρισιν Id. 29.19.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: strike out of, χειρῶν δʼ ἔκβαλλε κύπελλα Od. 2.396, cf. Theoc. 22.210 ; ἐκβάλλεθʼ..τευχέων πάλους throw them out of the urns, A. Eu. 742 : abs., δοῦρα ἐ. fell trees (prop., cut them out of the forest), Od. 5.244.
strike open, break in, ἐ. θύρετρα, πύλας, θύρας, E. Or. 1474, Hec. 1044, Lys. 3.23, D. 47.53.

children.label: III
children.definition: let fall, drop, χειρὸς δʼ ἔκβαλεν ἔγχος Il. 14.419 ; σφῦραν B. 17.28 ; ξίφος E. Andr. 629, cf. Ar. Lys. 156 ; οἰστούς X. An. 2.1.6 : metaph., ἦ ῥʼ ἅλιον ἔπος ἔκβαλον let fall an idle word, Il. 18.324 ; εἰ μὴ ὑπερφίαλον ἔπος ἔκβαλε Od. 4.503, cf. Hdt. 6.69, A. Ag. 1662, etc. ; ἐ. ῥῆμα Pl. R. 473e : abs., utter, speak, D.L. 9.7 ; shed, δάκρυα δʼ ἔκβαλε θερμά Od. 19.362 ; ἐ. ἕρκος ὀδόντων cast, shed oneʼs teeth, Sol. 27, cf. E. Cyc. 644, etc. ; throw up blood, S. Ant. 1238 ; spit out, Thphr. HP 4.8.4 ; ἐκβαλεῦσι τὰς κούρας their eyes will drop out, prov. of covetous persons, Herod. 4.64.

children.label: IV
children.definition: throw away, cast aside, reject, εὐμένειαν, χάριν, S. OC 631, 636, cf. Plb. 1.14.4 ; προγόνων παλαιὰ θέσμια E. Fr. 360.45 ; θεούς Ar. Nu. 1477 ; recall, repudiate, ἐ. λόγους Pl. Cri. 46b ; annul, τοὔπος S. OT 849 ; remove an official from his post, D. 21.87 ; drive an actor from the stage, Id. 19.337 : metaph., of a politician, Pl. Ax. 368d : — Pass., Ar. Eq. 525 ; ἐκβάλλεσθαι ἄξια Antipho 4.3.1.

children.label: V
children.definition: lose, properly by oneʼs own fault, φρένας, τἀγαθόν. S. Ant. 649, Aj. 965, cf. Ar. Eq. 404, Ec. 75.
